revision.comment: category renamed per [[Wikipedia:Categories_for_discussion/Log/2018_March_24#Category:Best_companies_to_work_for_awards]]
revision.text:
'''100 Best Workplaces in Europe''' is a ranking of the 100 workplaces in [[Europe]] performed each year by the [[Financial Times]], in partnership with [[Great Place to Work]]. The list is based on [[employee]] surveys and a review of the company's culture. Two thirds of the total score is from employee responses to a 57 question [[Statistical survey|survey]] on the culture of the company. The rest of the score is based on [[demographics]], pay, benefits, [[organizational culture|culture]], and community involvement.
The 2007 survey winner was the car manufacturer [[Ferrari]] of [[Italy]].
==External links== *[http://www.ft.com/reports/bestwork2007/ 100 Best Workplaces in Europe]
{{DEFAULTSORT:100 Best Workplaces In Europe}} [[Category:Working conditions]] [[Category:Survey methodology]] [[Category:Employer awards]] [[Category:Works about labor and the labor movement]]

[[S&P 100|S&P 100 component]]
[[S&P 500|S&P 500 component]] | ISIN = IE00B4BNMY34 | industry = [[Professional services]]
[[Technology services]] | foundation = {{start date and age|1989}} | location = [[Dublin]], [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]] | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = {{Unbulleted list|[[Pierre Nanterme]] ([[Chairman]] and [[Chief executive officer|CEO]]){{cite web|url=http://www.accenture.com/us-en/company/people/Pages/pierre-nanterme.aspx |title=Accenture profile: Pierre Nanterme |work=Accenture.com |accessdate=2 February 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110202093827/http://www.accenture.com/us-en/company/people/Pages/pierre-nanterme.aspx |archivedate=2 February 2011 |df=dmy }}{{cite web|url=http://newsroom.accenture.com/news/accenture-names-ceo-pierre-nanterme-to-additional-position-of-chairman-effective-feb-1-2013.htm|title=Accenture newsletter: Accenture names CEO|work=Accenture.com|accessdate=19 April 2013}}|David Rowland ([[Chief financial officer|CFO]])|Jo Deblaere ([[Chief operating officer|COO]])}} | services = [[strategic management|Strategy]], [[business consulting|consulting]], [[Computer|digital]], [[technology]], [[business operations|operations]], services, and solutions{{cite web |url=https://www.accenture.com/us-en/company.aspx |title=About Accenture |author = |date= |website= |publisher= |access-date=10 December 2015 }} | revenue = {{nowrap| US$39.6 billion (2018){{cite news |title=Accenture Q4 FY 2018 performance |url=https://newsroom.accenture.com/subjects/financial-earnings/accenture-reports-very-strong-fourth-quarter-and-full-year-fiscal-2018-results.tekdownload|publisher=Accenture.com |accessdate=27 September 2018}} }} | operating_income = US$5.84 billion (2018) | net_income = US$4.06 billion (2018) | assets = US$24.45 billion (2018) | equity = US$10.36 billion (2018) | num_employees = 459,000 (2018){{cite web |url=https://newsroom.accenture.com/fact-sheet/ |title=Fact sheet |publisher=Accenture |accessdate=1 September 2018}} | homepage = {{URL|http://www.accenture.com/}} }} '''Accenture''' is a global [[management consulting]] and [[professional services]] firm that provides strategy, consulting, digital, technology and operations services. A [[Fortune Global 500]] company,{{cite news |url=http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fortune/global500/2011/snapshots/11019.html|title=Fortune Global 500 – The World's Biggest Companies - Accenture Profile 2011|publisher=CNN|accessdate=24 March 2014}} it has been incorporated in [[Dublin]], [[Ireland]], since 1 September 2009. In 2018, the company reported net revenues of $39.6 billion, with more than 459,000 employees serving clients in more than 200 cities in 120 countries.{{cite news |title=Accenture Financial Statements 2015|url=https://newsroom.accenture.com/subjects/financial-earnings/accenture-reports-very-strong-fourth-quarter-and-full-year-fiscal-2015-results.tekdownload|publisher=Accenture.com |date=24 September 2015 |accessdate=6 November 2015}} In 2015, the company had about 150,000 employees in [[India]],{{cite web|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/india-business/accenture-says-india-employees-have-to-specialise-or-go/articleshow/65144526.cms|title=Accenture says India employees have to specialise}} about 48,000 in the [[US]],{{cite news |title=Guess which Illinois company uses the most worker visas |last1=Marek |first1=Lynne |url=http://www.chicagobusiness.com/article/20160227/ISSUE01/302279994/guess-which-illinois-company-uses-the-most-worker-visas |newspaper=[[Crain's Chicago Business]] |date=27 February 2016 |accessdate=15 July 2016}} and about 50,000 in the [[Philippines]].{{cite web|author =Mini Joseph Tejaswi |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2012-07-18/job-trends/32730373_1_accenture-india-core-biometric-identification-system-avinash-vashistha |title=Accenture in India |publisher=Articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com |date=2012-07-18 |accessdate=2013-08-10}} Accenture's current clients include 95 of the Fortune Global 100 and more than three-quarters of the Fortune Global 500. Accenture common equity is listed on the [[New York Stock Exchange]], under the symbol ACN, and was added to the [[S&P 500|S&P 500 index]] on 5 July 2011. Accenture has five businesses; these are Accenture Strategy, Accenture Consulting, Accenture Digital, Accenture Technology, and Accenture Operations. == History == === Formation and early years === Accenture began as the business and technology consulting division of accounting firm [[Arthur Andersen]]{{cite news |title=Accenture To Add 500 Jobs in Chicago |last1= |first1= |url=http://chicago.cbslocal.com/2011/10/11/accenture-to-add-500-jobs-in-chicago/ |newspaper=[[WBBM-TV]] |date=11 October 2011 |accessdate=10 December 2015}} in the early 1950s when it conducted a feasibility study for [[General Electric]] to install a computer at [[Appliance Park]] in [[Louisville, Kentucky]],{{cite news |title=Joseph Glickauf Jr. 1912-2005 |last1=Brachear |first1=Manya A. |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2005-07-28/news/0507280218_1_arthur-andersen-electronic-computer-ham-radio-operator |newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]] |date=28 July 2005 |accessdate=10 December 2015}} which led to GE's installation of a [[UNIVAC I]] computer and printer,{{cite news |title=GE's Appliance Park Still an IT Innovator |last1=Betts |first1=Mitch |url=http://www.computerworld.com/article/2590401/computer-hardware/ge-s-appliance-park-still-an-it-innovator.html |magazine=[[Computerworld]] |date=29 January 2001 |accessdate=10 December 2015}} believed to be the first commercial use of a computer in the U.S.{{cite news |title=The Univac I: First in the field |last1=Betts |first1=Mitch |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=s7vRlroiLwsC&pg=PT26&dq=the+univac+I:+first+in+the+field&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwixt7jAx9TJAhXDHD4KHawvBl4Q6AEIHTAA#v=onepage&q=the%20univac%20I%3A%20first%20in%20the%20field&f=false |magazine=[[Computerworld]] |date=2 July 1990 |accessdate=10 December 2015}} [[Joseph Glickauf]], an early pioneer of computer consulting, held a position as head of Arthur Andersen's administrative services division. ===Split from Arthur Andersen=== In 1989, [[Arthur Andersen]] and Andersen Consulting became separate units of [[Andersen Worldwide Société Coopérative]] (AWSC). Throughout the 1990s, there was increasing tension between Andersen Consulting and [[Arthur Andersen]]. Andersen Consulting was paying Arthur Andersen up to 15% of its profits each year (a provision of the 1989 split was that the more profitable unit – whether AA or AC – pay the other the 15 percent), while at the same time Arthur Andersen was competing with Andersen Consulting through its own newly established business consulting service line called Arthur Andersen Business Consulting (AABC). This dispute came to a head in 1998 when Andersen Consulting put the 15% transfer payment for that year and future years into [[escrow]] and issued a claim for breach of contract against AWSC and Arthur Andersen. In August 2000, as a result of the conclusion of arbitration with the [[International Chamber of Commerce]], Andersen Consulting broke all contractual ties with AWSC and Arthur Andersen. As part of the arbitration settlement, Andersen Consulting paid the sum held in escrow (then $1.2 billion) to Arthur Andersen, and was required to change its name, resulting in the entity being renamed Accenture.{{cite news |last=Martin |first=Mitchell |date=8 August 2000 |title=Arbitrator's Ruling Goes Against Accounting Arm : Consultants Win Battle Of Andersen |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/08/08/business/worldbusiness/08iht-consult.2.t.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |location=[[New York City]] |publisher=[[The New York Times Company]] |accessdate=1 March 2014}} === Emergence of Accenture === On 1 January 2001, Andersen Consulting adopted its current name, "Accenture". The word "Accenture" is supposedly derived from "Accent on the future". The name "Accenture" was submitted by Kim Petersen, a Danish employee from the company's Oslo, Norway office, as a result of an internal competition. Accenture felt that the name should represent its will to be a global consulting leader and high performer, and also intended that the name should not be offensive in any country in which Accenture operates.[http://www.informationweek.com/news/6509708 Andersen Consulting Changing Name To Accenture – 26 Oct. 2000]; InformationWeek [[File:AccentureNYSE.jpg|thumb|right|Accenture's banner hanging on the [[New York Stock Exchange]] ([[NYSE]]) building for its initial public offering on 19 July 2001.]] On 19 July 2001, Accenture's initial public offering ([[initial public offering|IPO]]) was priced at $14.50 per share, and the shares began trading on the [[New York Stock Exchange]] (NYSE); [[Goldman Sachs]] and [[Morgan Stanley]] served as its lead underwriters. Accenture stock closed the day at $15.17, with the day's high at $15.25. On the first day of the IPO, Accenture raised nearly $1.7 billion.[http://money.cnn.com/2001/07/19/deals/accenture/index.htm Accenture IPO gains in first trades – 19 Jul. 2001]; CNN Money === Bermuda headquarters === In October 2002, the Congressional [[Government Accountability Office|General Accounting Office]] (GAO) identified Accenture as one of four publicly traded federal contractors that were incorporated in a tax haven.[http://www.gao.gov/new.items/d03194r.pdf Information on Federal Contractors That Are Incorporated Offshore]; United States General Accounting Office; 1 October 2002 The other three, unlike Accenture, were incorporated in the United States before they re-incorporated in a tax haven, thereby lowering their US taxes. Critics, most notably former [[CNN]] journalist [[Lou Dobbs]],{{cite news|last=Dobbs|first=Lou|title=Exporting America|url=http://money.cnn.com/2004/03/09/commentary/dobbs/dobbs/index.htm|accessdate=3 May 2011|publisher=CNN|date=9 March 2004}} have reported Accenture's decision to incorporate in Bermuda as a US [[tax avoidance]] ploy, because they viewed Accenture as having been a US-based company.[http://www.house.gov/delauro/press/2004/accenture_06_01_04.html] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070503215542/http://www.house.gov/delauro/press/2004/accenture_06_01_04.html|date=3 May 2007}} The GAO itself did not characterize Accenture as having been a US-based company; it stated that "prior to incorporating in Bermuda, Accenture was operating as a series of related partnerships and corporations under the control of its partners through the mechanism of contracts with a Swiss coordinating entity."{{cite web|title=Information on Federal Contractors That Are Incorporated Offshore|url=https://www.gao.gov/assets/100/91572.html|website=gao.gov|publisher=General Accounting Office|accessdate=4 December 2017}} Accenture engaged in an [[NHS Connecting for Health|IT overhaul project]] for the [[National Health Service]] (NHS) in 2003, making headlines when it withdrew from the contract in 2006 over disputes related to delays and cost overruns.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2006/sep/28/news.business|title=Accenture to quit NHS technology overhaul|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=18 July 2014}} The government of the [[United Kingdom]] ultimately abandoned the project five years later for the same reasons.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/health-and-families/health-news/nhs-pulls-the-plug-on-its-11bn-it-system-2330906.html|title=NHS pulls the plug on its £11bn IT system|publisher=The Independent|accessdate=18 July 2014}} ===Ireland headquarters === Accenture announced on 26 May 2009 that its board of directors unanimously approved changing the company's place of incorporation from [[Bermuda]] to [[Ireland]] and would become '''Accenture plc'''.{{cite web|url=http://newsroom.accenture.com/article_display.cfm?article_id=4830 |title=Accenture Newsroom: Accenture Announces Proposed Change of Incorporation to Ireland |publisher=newsroom.accenture.com |date=26 May 2009 |accessdate=6 August 2010}} Accenture was chosen to replace [[CGI Group]] as the lead contractor for [[HealthCare.gov]] in January 2014.{{cite web|title=Accenture chosen as lead contractor of Obamacare website|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/accenture-chosen-lead-contractor-obamacare-website-government-220550193--sector.html|publisher=Yahoo!|accessdate=28 February 2014}} In December 2014, Accenture won a $563 million contract to provide ongoing maintenance, software development and technology support for HealthCare.gov through 2019.[http://www.beckershospitalreview.com/healthcare-information-technology/accenture-wins-new-563m-contract-for-healthcare-gov.html Becker's Healthcare] In July 2015, the United States Department of Defense awarded a major [[Electronic Health Records]] contract to [[Cerner]], [[Leidos]] and Accenture. The contract valued $4.33 billion will serve 55 hospitals and 600 clinics. Accenture Federal Services and Leidos will play the role of configuration specialist, while Cerner is the prime contractor.{{cite web|author=Sy Mukherjee|url=http://www.healthcaredive.com/news/cerner-leidos-accenture-win-massive-43b-defense-department-ehr-contra/403130/| title=Cerner, Leidos, & Accenture win massive $4.3B Defense Department EHR contract|work=Healthcare Dive|date=30 July 2015|accessdate=27 August 2017}} On 29 August 2017, [[Apple Inc.|Apple Inc]]. announced a partnership with Accenture to create [[iOS]] business solutions.{{Cite news|url=https://www.apple.com/newsroom/2017/08/apple-and-accenture-partner-to-create-ios-business-solutions/|title=Apple and Accenture partner to create iOS business solutions|work=Apple Newsroom|access-date=2017-08-31|language=en-US}} In June 2018, Accenture generated controversy over the amount the firm has been charging to recruit 7,500 [[U.S. Customs and Border Protection|Customs and Border Protection]] officers. Under the $297 million contract, Accenture had been charging the US Government nearly $40,000 per hire, which is more than the annual salary of the average officer.{{cite web |url=https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2018/06/border-patrol-is-so-desperate-for-new-agents-its-spending-millions-to-help-recruits-finish-their-applications-1/ |title= Border Patrol Is So Desperate for New Agents, It’s Spending Millions to Help Recruits Finish Their Applications |author =NOAH LANARD |date=14 June 2018 |accessdate=19 June 2018}} == Finances == For the fiscal year 2018, Accenture reported earnings of US$4.060 billion, with an annual revenue of US$41.603 billion, an increase of 13.2% over the previous fiscal cycle. Accenture's shares traded at over $159 per share, and its market capitalization was valued at over US$104.2 billion in October 2018.{{cite web|url=https://www.macrotrends.net/stocks/charts/ACN/accenture/total-assets|title=Accenture Total Assets 2006-2018 {{!}} ACN|website=www.macrotrends.net|access-date=2018-10-29}} {| class="wikitable float-left" style="text-align: right;" |- !Year !Revenue
in mil. USD$ !Net income
in mil. USD$ !Total Assets
in mil. USD$ !Price per Share
in USD$ !Employees |- |2005 |17,098 |940 |8,957 |19.63 | |- |2006 |18,228 |973 |9,497 |24.22 | |- |2007 |21,453 |1,243 |10,747 |31.04 | |- |2008 |25,314 |1,692 |12,399 |29.00 | |- |2009 |23,171 | 1,590 |12,256 |28.02 | |- |2010 |23,094 | 1,781 |12,835 |35.20 | |- |2011 |27,353 |2,278 |15,732 |47.23 | |- |2012 |29,778 |2,554 |16,665 |54.58 | |- |2013 |30,394 |3,282 |16,867 |67.91 |275,000 |- |2014 |31,875 |2,941 |17,930 |74.87 |305,000 |- |2015 |32,914 | 3,054 |18,203 |91.88 |358,000 |- |2016 |34,798 |4,112 |20,609 |108.54 |384,000 |- |2017 |36,765 |3,445 |22,690 |126.73 |425,000 |- |2018 |41,603 |4,060 |24,449 |159.92 |459,000 |} ==Services and operations== [[File:Spread of Accenture's offices around the world.svg|thumb|A worldmap showing the countries where Accenture has operations as of 2016]] * Accenture Strategy provides business strategy, technology strategy and operations strategy services.{{cite news |title=Analyst Commentary: Accenture's digital push will boost consulting prospects |url=http://www.professionaloutsourcingmagazine.net/newsitems/analyst-commentary-accentures-digital-push-will-boost-consulting-prospects |newspaper=Professional Outsourcing Resources |date=3 January 2014 |accessdate=30 January 2014}} * Accenture Consulting provides technology, business and management consulting.{{cite web|title = Accenture Consulting|url = https://www.accenture.com/us-en/consulting-index|website = www.accenture.com|accessdate = 2015-09-02}} * Accenture Digital provides [[digital marketing]], [[analytics]] and [[mobile computing|mobility]] services.{{cite news |title=Accenture launches digital marketing capabilities. Should agencies worry? |author =Rayana Pandey |url=http://www.marketing-interactive.com/accenture-launches-digital-marketing-capabilities-agencies-worry/ |newspaper=[[Marketing (magazine)|Marketing]] |date=5 December 2013 |accessdate=30 January 2014}} * Accenture Technology focuses on technology solutions, implementation, delivery, and research & development, including its Technology Labs for emerging technologies.{{cite web |url=http://allthingsd.com/20130605/former-hp-labs-head-prith-banerjee-joins-accenture/ |title=Former HP Labs Head Prith Banerjee Joins Accenture |author =Arik Hesseldahl |date=5 June 2013 |work=[[All Things Digital|All Things D]] |publisher= |accessdate=18 February 2015}} * Accenture Operations focuses on an "as-a-service" model of service delivery. This includes [[business process outsourcing]], [[IT service management|IT services]], [[Cloud computing|cloud services]], [[Managed services|managed operations]], [[Computer security|security]] and infrastructure services.{{cite news |title=Accenture’s offensive on the $5bn digital opportunity |author =Stuart Lauchlan |url=http://diginomica.com/2014/09/25/accentures-offensive-5bn-digital-opportunity/ |work=Diginomica |date=25 September 2014 |accessdate=30 January 2015}} == Marketing, branding and identity == In 2011, Accenture launched a new campaign of results-based ads featuring clients such as [[Marriott International|Marriott]], [[Unilever]] and the [[Royal Shakespeare Company]] alongside its slogan “High performance. Delivered”.{{cite news |title=Accenture Calls on Clients to Help Make a Statement |last1=Elliott |first1=Stuart |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/17/business/media/accenture-wants-to-stand-out-in-a-crowded-category.html?_r=0 |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=17 November 2011 |accessdate=10 December 2015}} As of 2017, [[Interbrand]] ranked Accenture No. 37 on its list of best global brands.{{cite web |url=http://interbrand.com/best-brands/best-global-brands/2017/ranking/ |title=Best Global Brands 2017 Rankings |date=2017 |publisher=[[Interbrand]] |accessdate=9 February 2018}} The brand consultancy noted Accenture's focus on branding and marketing of its Accenture Strategy, Accenture Consulting, Accenture Digital, Accenture Technology and Accenture Operations divisions.{{cite web |url=http://interbrand.com/best-brands/best-global-brands/2015/ranking/accenture/ |title=Best Global Brands 2015 |author = |date= |work= |publisher=[[Interbrand]] |accessdate=10 December 2015}} From at least 2005{{Citation |author = Jennifer Pellet |publication-date= 1 August 2005 |title= Pursuing high performance: chief executives can, in fact, stay ahead of emerging global competitors. |publisher= [[Chief Executive (magazine)|Chief Executive]] |page=66|issue=211 |url= http://chiefexecutive.net/pursuing-high-performance|accessdate=13 October 2013}} until December 2009, Accenture used [[Tiger Woods]] as a celebrity spokesperson and advertised using the [[service mark]] "Go on, be a Tiger" and the ancillary statement "We know what it takes to be a Tiger" in association with his image. On 13 December 2009 after details of [[Tiger Woods#Infidelity scandal and fallout|Woods' extra-marital affairs]] were exposed, the company terminated Woods' six-year sponsorship deal.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/8411091.stm |title=Accenture cuts Tiger Woods sponsorship deal |publisher=BBC News |date=14 December 2009 |accessdate=6 August 2010}} The company uses a standardised system of branding, with extensive use of the font [[Graphik (typeface)|Graphik]].{{cite web |url=http://www.underconsideration.com/brandnew/archives/new_logo_and_identity_for_accenture.php#.WKcRxDw8LYW |title=New logo and identity for Accenture |date=16 February 2017 |publisher=Brand New |accessdate=18 April 2017}} From 1999, the firm's culture was parodied by the webcomic ''Bigtime Consulting'', operated pseudonymously by its San Francisco-based employee James Sanchez.{{cite web|title=Bigtime Consulting archive|url=http://www.bigtimeconsulting.org/|publisher='Bigtime Consulting'}}{{cite web|last1=Gardner|first1=Jim|title=Web satire causes Bigtime headaches for Andersen|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/stories/2000/12/11/tidbits.html|website=San Francisco Business Times|accessdate=22 November 2015}} Accenture actively manages their Wikipedia presence using the public relations company [[Burson-Marsteller]] and advertising agency Beutler Ink.{{cite web|url=https://dokumen.tips/business/beutler-ink-capabilities-deck.html |title=Beutler Ink Capabilities Deck |publisher=Dokumen.tips |date= |accessdate=2018-11-14}} === Diversity policy === Accenture has implemented policies to reduce gendered discrimination such as gender neutral bathrooms and gender neutral dress-codes. Denise Norris, a transgender activist and Accenture employee, said “In cultures that don’t embrace gender diversity, Accenture’s workplace can become a haven, a safe space for our transgender employees.”{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/capital/story/20150708-transgender-at-the-office|title=Transgender, at the office|last=Alsop|first=Ronald|language=en|access-date=2018-04-16}} ==Awards== *In 2016, Accenture was ranked No. 289 on the [[Forbes Global 2000]] list.{{cite news |title=The World’s Biggest Public Companies |url=https://www.forbes.com/global2000/list/#tab:overall |magazine=[[Forbes]] |date=2016 |accessdate=15 July 2016}} *In 2016, Accenture was ranked No. 312 on the [[Fortune Global 500]] list.{{cite news |title=312: Accenture |url=http://beta.fortune.com/global500/accenture-312?iid=sr-link7 |newspaper=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] |date=2016 |accessdate=17 October 2016}} *In 2016, the firm was named 15th in the Top 50 Companies for Diversity by DiversityInc.{{cite web |url=http://www.diversityinc.com/the-diversityinc-top-50-companies-for-diversity-2016/ |title=The DiversityInc Top 50 Companies for Diversity |date=2016 |publisher=DiversityInc |accessdate=18 April 2017}} *In 2017, Accenture was ranked No. 272 on the [[Forbes Global 2000]] list.{{cite news |title=The World’s Biggest Public Companies |url=https://www.forbes.com/global2000/list/#search:Accenture |magazine=[[Forbes]] |date=2017 |accessdate=26 July 2017}} *In 2017, Accenture was ranked No. 305 on the [[Fortune Global 500]] list.{{cite news |title=Global 500 |url=http://fortune.com/global500/list/filtered?searchByName=accenture |newspaper=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] |date=2017 |accessdate=26 July 2017}} *In 2017, the firm was named 14th in the Top 50 Companies for Diversity by DiversityInc.{{cite web |url=http://www.diversityinc.com/the-diversityinc-top-50-companies-for-diversity-2017/ |title=The DiversityInc Top 50 Companies for Diversity |date=2017 |publisher=DiversityInc |accessdate=26 July 2017}} *Accenture is one of 12 best management consulting firms of 2017 in America according to [[Forbes]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jeffkauflin/2017/04/19/americas-best-management-consulting-firms-2017/#304aa4974910|title=America's Best Management Consulting Firms 2017|last=|first=|date=|work=Forbes|access-date=2017-08-16|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en}} *In 2018, [[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune magazine]] named it as the world's most admired Information Technology Services company.{{cite news |title=World's Most Admired Companies |url=http://fortune.com/worlds-most-admired-companies/accenture/ |newspaper=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] |date=2018 |accessdate=9 February 2018}} *In 2018, the [[Ethisphere Institute]] named Accenture one of the world's most ethical companies for the 11th time{{cite web |url=http://www.worldsmostethicalcompanies.com/honorees/ |title=The 2018 World’s Most Ethical Companies Honoree List |date=2018 |publisher=Ethisphere Institute |accessdate=17 May 2018}} *''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'' named Accenture one of the [[100 Best Companies to Work For]] from 2009 to 2018{{cite web |url=http://fortune.com/best-companies/accenture/ |title=Accenture: #60 |date=2018 |publisher=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] |accessdate=17 May 2018}} *''CR Magazine'' named Accenture No. 2 in its top 100 Best Corporate Citizens list for 2018{{cite web |url=http://www.3blassociation.com/insights/corporate-responsibility-magazine-announces-2018-100-best-corporate-citizens |title=Corporate Responsibility Magazine Announces 2018 100 Best Corporate Citizens |author=Margie Kuchinski |date=3 May 2018 |publisher=3BL Association |accessdate=17 May 2018}} *In 2018, Accenture was ranked No. 288 on the [[Forbes Global 2000]] list.{{cite news |title=The World’s Largest Public Companies |url=https://www.forbes.com/global2000/list/#search:Accenture |magazine=[[Forbes]] |date=2018 |accessdate=28 August 2018}} *In 2018, Accenture was ranked No. 316 on the [[Fortune Global 500]] list.{{cite news |title=Global 500 |url=http://fortune.com/global500/list/filtered?searchByName=Accenture |magazine=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] |date=2018 |accessdate=28 August 2018}} *In 2018, the firm was named 9th in the Top 50 Companies for Diversity by DiversityInc.{{cite web |url=https://www.diversityinc.com/st/DI_Top_50 |title=The 2018 DiversityInc Top 50 Companies for Diversity |date=2018 |publisher=DiversityInc |accessdate=26 July 2017}} ==See also== {{Portal|Companies}} *[[List of IT consulting firms]] * [[Software industry in Telangana]] * page.title: Ahmed bin Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud

revision.text:
{{distinguish|Ahmed bin Fahd bin Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2015}} {{Infobox royalty | name = Ahmed bin Salman | title = | image = | caption = | spouse = Lamia bint Mishaal bin Saud bin Abdulaziz Al Saud | issue = 5 | full name = Ahmed bin Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud | styles = | succession = | reign = | reign-type = | predecessor = | house = [[House of Saud]] | father = [[Salman bin Abdulaziz]] | mother = Sultana bint Turki al Sudairi | birth_date = 17 November 1958 | birth_place = [[Riyadh]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|2002|7|22|1958|11|17}} | death_place= Riyadh | burial_date = 23 July 2002 | burial_place = [[Al Oud cemetery]], Riyadh | religion = [[Wahhabi]] [[Hanbali]] [[Sunni Islam]] }}
'''[[Prince]] Ahmed bin Salman al-Saud''' (17 November 1958 – 22 July 2002) was a member of the [[House of Saud]] and a media executive who was also a major figure in international [[Thoroughbred horse race|Thoroughbred horse racing]].
==Early life== Prince Ahmed was born in [[Riyadh]] on 17 November 1958.<ref name=aboutcom>{{cite web|title=Prince Ahmed bin Salman 1958 - 2002|url=http://horseracing.about.com/library/weekly/aa072302a.htm|work=About.com|accessdate=19 May 2012|date=23 July 2002}}</ref><ref name=HRaces>{{cite web|title=Prince Ahmed bin Salman 1958 - 2002|url=http://www.horse-races.net/library/aa072202.htm|work=Horse Races|accessdate=23 May 2012}}</ref> He was the third eldest son of [[Salman bin Abdulaziz]], [[King of Saudi Arabia]], and Sultana bin Turki Al Sudairi who died in July 2011.<ref>{{cite web|title=Princess Sultana bint Turki Al Sudairy dies |url=http://www.lifeinriyadh.com/princess-sultana-bint-turki-al-sudairy-dies |work=Arab News |accessdate=4 May 2012 |date=1 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121015154950/http://www.lifeinriyadh.com/princess-sultana-bint-turki-al-sudairy-dies |archivedate=15 October 2012 }}</ref> She was a daughter of Prince Salman's uncle, Turki bin Ahmed al Sudairi,<ref name=sgaz/> a former governor of [[Asir Province|Asir]].<ref name=datsultana>{{cite web|title=Sultana bint Ahmad bin Muhammad al Sudairi|url=http://www.datarabia.com/royals/viewBio.do?id=176248|work=Datarabia|accessdate=8 May 2012}}</ref> Ahmed bin Salman is full brother of [[Fahd bin Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud|Prince Fahd]], [[Sultan bin Salman Al Saud|Prince Sultan]], [[Abdulaziz bin Salman Al Saud|Prince Abdulaziz]], [[Faisal bin Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud|Prince Faisal]] and Princess Hassa.<ref>{{cite web|title=Family Tree of Salman bin Abdulaziz bin Abdul Rahman Al Saud|url=http://www.datarabia.com/royals/famtree.do?id=176822|work=Datarabia|accessdate=1 May 2012}}</ref><ref name=siasat11>{{cite news|title=Kingdom mourns loss of princess|url=http://www.siasat.com/english/news/kingdom-mourns-loss-princess|accessdate=26 May 2012|newspaper=The Siasat Daily|date=3 August 2011}}</ref>
==Education== Prince Ahmed first studied at [[Colorado School of Mines]].<ref name=anews2302>{{cite news|title=Prince Ahmad ibn Salman passes away|url=http://www.arabnews.com/node/222758|accessdate=16 July 2012|newspaper=Arab News|date=23 July 2002}}</ref> He then graduated from [[Wentworth Military Academy]].<ref name=anews2302/> After graduation, he returned to Saudi Arabia and joined the Saudi Air Force.
Later, Ahmed bin Salman continued his studies in the US and attended [[University of California, Irvine]].<ref name=aboutcom/><ref name=HRaces/> He studied comparative culture and graduated from the university in the early 1980s.<ref>{{cite news|author=David Wharton|title=A Charming Prince Is Lost|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2002/jul/23/sports/sp-prince23|accessdate=23 May 2012|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|date=23 July 2002}}</ref><ref name=nytmay2002>{{cite news|author=Joe Drape|title=Horse racing; A Prince's Passion finally Pays Off|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/05/18/sports/horse-racing-a-prince-s-passion-finally-pays-off.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm|accessdate=23 May 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=18 May 2002}}</ref>
==Career== In Saudi Arabia Ahmed bin Salman joined armed forces before dealing with business.<ref name=Sharaf2001>{{cite book|author=Sabri Sharaf|title=The House of Saud in Commerce: A Study of Royal Entrepreneurship in Saudi Arabia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=51Bb8Ix7xw8C&pg=PA124|accessdate=2 April 2013|year=2001|publisher=Sharaf Sabri|isbn=978-81-901254-0-6|page=142}}</ref> After leaving armed forces in 1985 he established ASAS, a company which specialized in maintenance and contracting.<ref name=anews2302/> He became chairman of [[Saudi Research and Marketing Group]] (SRMG) in 1989,<ref name=anews2302/><ref name=spocket>{{cite journal|author=Abdul Bari Atwan|author2=Jihad Khazen|title=In the Saudi pocket|journal=Index on Censorship|year=1996|volume=25|issue=2|pages=50–55|doi=10.1080/03064229608536032}}</ref> a media company with offices in [[Riyadh]] and [[Jeddah]] as well as in [[London]]<ref name=HRaces/> and [[Washington D.C.]]<ref name=bloodhorse>{{cite web|author=Ray Paulick|title=Profile of an Owner: Prince Ahmed bin Salman|url=http://www.bloodhorse.com/horse-racing/articles/4563/profile-of-an-owner-prince-ahmed-bin-salman|work=Blood Horse|accessdate=23 May 2012|date=9 August 2001}}</ref> Prince Ahmed also bought 80% of the daily, ''[[Asharq Al Awsat]]'', which is a publication of the SRMG.<ref name=Rugh2004>{{cite book|author=William A. Rugh|title=The Arab Mass Media: Newspapers, Radio, and Television in Arab Politics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UGfbluSa4N8C&pg=PA169|accessdate=26 February 2013|year=2004|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-275-98212-6|page=169}}</ref>
SRMG is reported to be the largest media company in the [[Middle East]].<ref name=wikileaks2009>{{cite web|title=İdeological and ownership trends in the Saudi media|url=http://www.cablegatesearch.net/cable.php?id=09RIYADH651|work=Wikileaks|accessdate=1 May 2012|date=11 May 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130116083750/http://www.cablegatesearch.net/cable.php?id=09RIYADH651|archive-date=16 January 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> However, the business was worth [[$ (Dollars)|$]]90 million when Prince Ahmed took over the company. Its assets were worth nearly $533 million at the period when he died.<ref name=ppg23702/> After his death his full brother [[Faisal bin Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud|Prince Faisal]] became the chairman of SRMG.<ref name=Rugh2004/>
==Involvement in horse racing== Ahmed bin Salman began horseracing activity with his college friend Richard Mulhall as his [[horse trainer]] and eventually his manager of racing operations.<ref name=HRaces/> First he bought a gray stallion named Jumping Hill.<ref name=nytmay2002/> Then, Prince Ahmed began racing under the name Universal Stable until 1994.<ref name=HRaces/> Later, he created [[the Thoroughbred Corporation]]<ref name=aboutcom/> and became the principal partner of this company.<ref name=HRaces/> In 1999 Ahmed bin Salman won [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] with [[Oath (horse)|Oath]].<ref name=aboutcom/> He also won the Preakness and Belmont Stakes with the 2001 horse of the year, [[Point Given]].<ref name=Ctribune>{{cite news|title=Ahmed bin Salman bin Abdulaziz|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2002-07-28/news/0207280133_1_chicago-teachers-union-labor-elton-john|accessdate=23 May 2012|newspaper=Chicago Tribune|date=28 July 2002}}</ref> He also achieved another dream by winning the [[Kentucky Derby]] with [[War Emblem]] in May 2002, making him the first Arab horse owner to win this race.<ref name=aboutcom/><ref name=ppg23702>{{cite news|title=Saudi prince, a top owner o racehorses|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=rORRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=RnADAAAAIBAJ&pg=4772,2639066&dq=salman+bin+abdulaziz&hl=en|accessdate=14 September 2012|newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|date=23 July 2002}}</ref> War Emblem was sold to Prince Ahmed just three weeks before the race after the horse won [[Illinois Derby|the Illinois Derby]]. The price of the horse was [[$ (Dollars)|$]]900,000.<ref name=ppg23702/> Prince Faisal, his brother, succeeded him as the head of the Thoroughbred Corporation after his death in 2002.<ref name=good1aug>{{cite news|author=Kristin Ingwell Goode|title=Prince Faisal Salman to Head Thoroughbred Corporation|url=http://www.bloodhorse.com/horse-racing/articles/10721/prince-faisal-salman-to-head-thoroughbred-corporation|accessdate=19 April 2013|work=Blood Horse|date=1 August 2002}}</ref><ref name=law1aug>{{cite news|author=David Lawrence|title=Faisal to step into the breach|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Faisal+to+step+into+the+breach.-a089955466|accessdate=19 April 2013|newspaper=The Racing Post|date=1 August 2002|location=London}}</ref>
Ahmed bin Salman also owned Spain, horse racing's all-time female money-winner.<ref name=HRaces/><ref name=Ctribune/> He is one of only four men to have raced both a Kentucky Derby winner and an Epsom Derby winner. The others are [[John W. Galbreath]], [[Michael Tabor]], and [[Paul Mellon]].<ref name=aboutcom/>
==Other positions== Ahmed bin Salman was appointed secretary-general of the Prince Fahd bin Salman Charitable Association for Kidney Patients and a member of the charity’s board of directors following the death of his elder brother [[Fahd bin Salman]] in 2001.<ref name=anews2001>{{cite news|title=Prince Ahmad named secretary-general of Prince Fahd charity|url=http://www.arabnews.com/node/214242|accessdate=24 May 2012|newspaper=Arab News|date=31 July 2001}}</ref>
==Personal life== Prince Ahmed is survived by his wife, Lamia bint Mishaal, daughter of [[Mishaal bin Saud Al Saud]].<ref name=bloodhorse/><ref>{{cite web|title=Family Tree of Ahmad bin Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud|url=http://www.datarabia.com/royals/famtree.do?id=176830|work=Datarabia|accessdate=1 May 2012}}</ref> He had four daughters and a son.<ref>{{cite news|author=Etab Noor|title=Prince Ahmad: A force behind Arab media|url=http://www.arabnews.com/news/460535|accessdate=9 August 2013|newspaper=Arab News|date=7 August 2013|location=Riyadh}}</ref> His family owns three percent of Saudi Research and Marketing Group.<ref name=wikileaks2009/>
==Death and funeral== Ahmed bin Salman died of [[Myocardial infarction|heart failure]] at age 43 in Riyadh on 22 July 2002.<ref name=nytimes>{{cite news|title=Saudis Mourn 2 Princes|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/07/24/world/saudis-mourn-2-princes.html?ref=ahmedbinsalman|accessdate=23 May 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=24 July 2002}}</ref> He was buried in [[Al Oud cemetery]] on 23 July 2002 after funeral prayers at the Imam Turki bin Abdullah mosque in Riyadh.<ref name=sgaz>{{cite news|author=Abdullah =Al Oraifij |title=Sultana, wife of Riyadh Emir, passes away |url=http://www.saudigazette.com.sa/index.cfm?method=home.regcon&contentid=20110803106640 |accessdate=9 August 2012 |newspaper=Saudi Gazette |date=3 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131228132942/http://www.saudigazette.com.sa/index.cfm?method=home.regcon&contentID=20110803106640 |archivedate=28 December 2013 }}</ref><ref name=usatoday/><ref name=an24702>{{cite news|title=Prince dies in car crash on way to Ahmad’s funeral|url=http://www.arabnews.com/node/222783|accessdate=14 August 2012|newspaper=Arab News|date=24 July 2002}}</ref> His cousin, Sultan bin Faisal bin Turki bin Abdullah, brother of [[Abdullah bin Faisal bin Turki|Abdullah bin Faisal]], was coming to Riyadh to participate in funeral prayers for Prince Ahmed when he was killed in a car crash. The cousins were buried together.<ref name=usatoday>{{cite news|last=Bradley|first=John R.|title=Prince Ahmed's cousin killed on way to funeral|url=https://www.usatoday.com/sports/horses/stories/2002-07-23-salman-funeral_x.htm|accessdate=9 August 2012|newspaper=USA Today|date=23 July 2002|agency=AP}}</ref><ref name=lmt>{{cite news|title=Second tragedy strikes Saudi Royal Family|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=JrNeAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6S8MAAAAIBAJ&pg=5287,2296672&dq=prince+turki+bin+abdulaziz&hl=en|accessdate=19 August 2012|newspaper=Lewiston Morning Tribune|date=24 July 2002|agency=AP|location=Riyadh}}</ref>
==War Emblem's win in the Preakness== With his college friend Richard Mulhall as trainer, he got into the racing business initially as Universal Stable.<ref name="horseracing.about.com">http://horseracing.about.com/library/weekly/aa072302a.htm</ref> In 1994 when the operation resurfaced as The Thoroughbred Corporation, with Mulhall retiring as a trainer and taking on the job of racing manager. Mulhall is currently the president of the operation. The pair would go on to racing greatness, both with sales purchases and homebreds. The Thoroughbred Corp.'s roster reads like a who's who of racing in the past decade, with such greats as Sharp Cat, Lear Fan, Jewel Princess, Windsharp, Military, Royal Anthem, Anees, Officer, Habibti, Spain, 2001 Horse of the Year Point Given, and this year's dual classic winner War Emblem.<ref name="horseracing.about.com"/> Currently Thoroughbred Corp. has approximately 60 horses in training mostly stabled with Bob Baffert, D. Wayne Lukas, and John Shireffs, along with 45 broodmares, mostly at Mill Ridge Farm in Lexington. His name will always be associated with War Emblem, his one Kentucky Derby winner, which he quipped was "one of the best investments I ever made in my life, besides buying oil in Saudi Arabia," after he won the Preakness. He bought a 90% share in the colt just three weeks before the Derby, and with the win, became the first Arab owner to capture the Roses.
==Legacy== [[Faisal bin Salman]] announced in 2004 that Prince Ahmad bin Salman Institute for Applied Media Training would be established to train journalists.<ref name=ar2004>{{cite news|title=Prince Ahmad Institute for Media Training Set Up|url=http://www.arabnews.com/node/257427|accessdate=21 May 2012|newspaper=Arab News|date=1 November 2004}}</ref>
==Alleged involvement in 9/11 attacks== In ''Why America Slept'' (2003), [[Gerald Posner]] claimed that Ahmed bin Salman (along with Sultan bin Faisal bin Turki bin Abdullah and Prince Fahd bin Turki bin Saud al-Kabir) had had ties to [[al-Qaeda]] and had advance knowledge of the [[September 11, 2001 attacks]]. All three died within days of each other, and soon after the [[CIA]] inquired about their possible connection to the attacks.<ref>{{cite news|last=McGeary|first=Johanna|title=Confessions of a Terrorist | url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,480226,00.html |accessdate=1 Apr 2016|newspaper=Time|date=31 Aug 2003}}</ref> The story was strongly denied by his family, who claimed that he admired the United States, spent a great deal of time at his home there in [[Bradbury, California]], and invested heavily in the American horse racing industry. His friends in American racing stated their knowledge of him and his attitudes made it impossible to believe the allegations.<ref>{{cite news|last=O'Keeffe|first=Michael|title=War Emblem owner dead but 9-11 rap has life of its own|url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2004-05-23/sports/18266386_1_prince-ahmed-prince-faisal-thoroughbred-corp|accessdate=1 May 2012|newspaper=NY Daily News|date=23 May 2004}}</ref>
==Ancestry== {{ahnentafel |collapsed=yes |align=center |ref=<ref name="datarabia">{{cite web|title=Royal Family Directory|url=http://www.datarabia.com/royals/famtree.do?id=176834|website=www.datarabia.com|accessdate=22 June 2017|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160318050546/http://datarabia.com/royals/famtree.do?id=176834|archivedate=18 March 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref> |boxstyle_1=background-color: #fcc; |boxstyle_2=background-color: #fb9; |boxstyle_3=background-color: #ffc; |boxstyle_4=background-color: #bfc; |boxstyle_5=background-color: #9fe; |1=1. '''Ahmed Al Saud''' |2=2. [[Salman of Saudi Arabia|Salman Al Saud]] |3=3. Sultana bint Turki Al Sudairi |4=4. [[Ibn Saud]] |5=5. [[Hussa bint Ahmed Al Sudairi|Hassa bint Ahmed Al Sudairi]] |6=6. Turki bin Ahmed Al Sudairi |8=8. [[Abdul Rahman bin Faisal]] |9=9. Sarah bint Ahmed Al Kabir bin Mohammed [[Al Sudairi]] |10=10. Ahmed bin Mohammed [[Al Sudairi]] (= 12) |11=11. Sharifa bint Ali bin Mohammed [[Al Suwaidi]] (= 13) |12=12. Ahmed bin Mohammed Al Sudairi (= 10) |13=13. Sharifa bint Ali bin Mohammed Al Suwaidi (= 11) |16=16. [[Faisal bin Turki bin Abdullah Al Saud]] |17=17. Sarah bint Mishari bin Abdulrahman bin Hassan Al Saud |18=18. Ahmed Al Kabir bin Mohammed bin Turki [[Al Sudairi]] |20=20. Mohammed bin Ahmed Al Kabir [[Al Sudairi]] (= 24) |22=22. Ali bin Mohammed [[Al Suwaidi]] (= 26) |24=24. Mohammed bin Ahmed Al Kabir Al Sudairi (= 20) |26=26. Ali bin Mohammed Al Suwaidi (= 22) }}
== References == {{Reflist|33em}}
==Other sources== * [[Gerald Posner|Posner, Gerald L.]] ''Why America Slept'' (2003) [[Random House]] {{ISBN|978-0-375-50879-0}} * Unger, Craig ''House of Bush, House of Saud'' (2004) [[Charles Scribner's Sons|Scribner]] {{ISBN|978-0-7432-5337-6}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 6 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta9)
revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2014}} {{Infobox person |image = PotupaAS.jpg |name = Alexander S. Potupa
Аляксандр Патупа |imagesize = 200px |nationality = |citizenship = [[Belarus]] |birth_date = {{Birth date|1945|3|21}} |birth_place = [[Sevastopol]] |death_date = {{Death date and age|2009|6|1|1945|3|21}} |death_place = [[Minsk]], Belarus |spouse = Lubov N. Potupa (b. 1955) |children =Elena Potoupa (b. 1975) and Andrei Potupa (b. 1976) |website = https://web.archive.org/web/20090614151346/http://potupa.iatp.by/ }} '''Alexander Sergeevich Potupa'''also Potoupa, Patupa ({{lang-be|Аляксандр Сяргеевіч Патупа}}; {{lang-ru|link=no|Александр Серге́евич Потупа}}; March 21, 1945 – June 1, 2009) was a [[Belarusian people|Belarusian]] philosopher, writer, scientist and human rights activist. ==Biography== Alexander Sergeevich Potupa was born in [[Sevastopol]], Russia on March 21, 1945, eventually moving to [[Yeysk]], where he went to school. He also became a [[chess master]]. From 1961 until his death, he lived in [[Minsk]], Belarus. In 1967 he graduated from [[Moscow State University]] with MS in [[Nuclear Physics]], [[Quantum Field Theory]]. In 1970 he received PhD in [[Theoretical Physics]] & Mathematics. By the time of his death Potupa had published approximately 50 works,[http://cdsweb.cern.ch/record/879127 "NARROW-RESONANCE APPROXIMATION AS A NECESSARY CONDITION FOR NUCLEAR DEMOCRACY AND HADRON MASS SPECTRUM."], ''[[OSTI]]'', Potupa, A S, January 1, 1969.[http://www.osti.gov/energycitations/product.biblio.jsp?osti_id=4103865 "CONCERNING EFFECTS OF STRUCTURE OF NUCLEAR SURFACES IN NEUTRON SCATTERING AT SMALL ANGLES."], ''[[OSTI]]'', Potupa, A.S. ; Tret'yakov, V.N., January 1, 1970.[http://www.osti.gov/energycitations/product.biblio.jsp?osti_id=4756131 "MODEL FOR QUASIPOTENTIAL HADRON DIFFRACTION."], ''[[OSTI]]'', Potupa, A.S., January 1, 1970.[http://www.osti.gov/energycitations/product.biblio.jsp?osti_id=4755879 "COMPLEX REGGE TRAJECTORIES AND THE RESONANT FIELD BOUNDARY."], ''[[OSTI]]'', Potupa, A.S., January 1, 1970.[http://www.osti.gov/energycitations/product.biblio.jsp?osti_id=4011269 "IDEALIZED MEASUREMENTS IN QUANTUM FIELD THEORY."], ''[[OSTI]]'', Potupa, A.S., January 1, 1971.[http://www.osti.gov/energycitations/product.biblio.jsp?osti_id=4754915 "DUALITY AND THE POMERANCHUK TRAJECTORY.".], ''[[OSTI]]'', Potupa, A.S., January 1, 1971.[http://www.osti.gov/energycitations/product.biblio.jsp?osti_id=4237285 "On general enunciation of droplet model of hadron diffraction."], ''[[OSTI]]'', Potupa, A.S., January 1, 1972.[http://www.osti.gov/energycitations/product.biblio.jsp?osti_id=4359207 "Multicluster model. Multiple generation of hadrons."], ''[[OSTI]]'', Potupa, A.S., January 1, 1973.[http://www.osti.gov/energycitations/product.biblio.jsp?osti_id=4333264 "Foundation for thermodynamics with large fluctuations in hadronic multiparticle production processes."], ''[[OSTI]]'', Fridman, A.S. ; Kuvshinov, V.I. ; Potupa, A.S. ; Zirkov, L.F., December 29, 1973.[http://www.osti.gov/energycitations/product.biblio.jsp?osti_id=4301112 "Theory of hadron reactions at very high energies."], ''[[OSTI]]'', Potupa, A.S., January 1, 1974.[http://www.osti.gov/energycitations/product.biblio.jsp?osti_id=4304125 "Analytical S-matrix program and adaptive interpretation of the theory of hadron processes."], ''[[OSTI]]'', Potupa, A.S., January 1, 1974.[http://www.osti.gov/energycitations/product.biblio.jsp?osti_id=4285339 "Stochastic model for the multiple generation of hadrons."], ''[[OSTI]]'', Potupa, A.S., April 1, 1974.[http://www.osti.gov/energycitations/product.biblio.jsp?osti_id=7241782 "New scaling in the pionization region of inclusive pp collision spectra at high energies."], ''[[OSTI]]'', Potupa, A.S. ; Skadorov, V.V. ; Fridman, A.S., May 5, 1976.[http://cdsweb.cern.ch/record/879127 "Growth of the height of the inclusive spectra and the average multiplicity in the rapid pionisation model."], ''[[CERN]]'', Potupa, A S ; Fridman, A S ; Skadorov, V V, January 1, 1978.[http://www.osti.gov/energycitations/product.biblio.jsp?osti_id=5295547 "Fast pionization at very high energies".], ''[[OSTI]]'', Potupa, A.S. ; Skadorov, V.V. ; Fridman, A.S., January 20, 1980.[http://www.springerlink.com/content/87410j4r661x33v5/ “Foundation for thermodynamics with large fluctuations in hadronic multiparticle production processes”.], [[SpringerLink]], A. S. Fridman, V. I. Kuvshinov, A. S. Potupa and L. F. Zirkov. August 31, 1973.[http://www.springerlink.com/content/q072223t4r460248 “Effects of second viscosity in cosmology”.], [[SpringerLink]],A. S. Potupa. December 3, 1976. made 30 appearances at international and national conferences[http://www.ilhr.org/ilhr/regional/belarus/updates/2000/39.html Helsinki-XXI] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101221162512/http://www.ilhr.org/ilhr/regional/belarus/updates/2000/39.html |date=December 21, 2010 }}, ''[[International League for Human Rights|ILHR]]'', September 17, 2000. in the areas of [[nuclear physics]], [[high energy physics]], [[cosmology]], [[electrodynamics]], and has done research work at [[National Academy of Sciences of Belarus|Physics Institute]] and [[Belarusian State University]]. Soon after the collapse of the [[Soviet Union]] Potupa decided to open a private company. Prior to 1988, there were only public/government businesses. From 1989 until 1996, Potupa was the President /Founder of [[Publishing company|Publishing & Printing Company]] "Eridan", which was the first Private publishing & printing company to open in Belarus. "Eridan", won the – Torch of [[Birmingham]] awarded for survival in a rough economic environment. Since 1992 he was a President of Future Studies Center (forecast and social research) where he had performed over 15 complex expert social polls. Potupa published over 100 publications and articles[http://potupa.iatp.by/articles.html List of articles and interviews.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071208120104/http://potupa.iatp.by/articles.html |date=December 8, 2007 }}, A. S. Potupa (Potupa.com){{Ru icon}} and made over 60 appearances in international and national conferences in the area of [[forecasting]], sociology, [[political science]], economics, and law. In 1995 he received a PhD in Philosophy & [[Futurology]] (strategic forecasting and information technology). Professor. Dr. Potupa was also a researcher & lecturer in [[future studies]]. His specialty was in [[strategic forecasting]], [[globalization]], futurogenic causality, models for Belarus & [[Commonwealth of Independent States|CIS]] development, sociology, cosmology, strategy for science. He died unexpectedly on June 1, 2009 at the Borovliani Hospital during a lung cancer treatment. The cause of death is [[thrombus]], a blood clot, which separated from his leg blocking path to both of his lungs. ==Occupation & Memberships== Occupations:
– President of Center for Future Studies (1992–2009)
– President of [http://en.ngo.by/projects/professional-organization/c1be68afae9c03de.html BAE] – Belarusian Association of Entrepreneurs (2001–2007), Honorable President of BAE (2008)
– President /Founder of Publishing & Printing Company "Eridan" (1989–1996), 1st Private publishing & printing company in Belarus. Professional and Other Memberships:
– [https://web.archive.org/web/20090801133606/http://www.wintecs.ru/mait.html IAIPT] {{Ru icon}} (International Academy of Informational Processes and Technologies)
– [http://www.ialba.org/eng/ IALBA] (International Academy of Leaders in Business & Administration)
– [[New York Academy of Science|NYAS]] (New York Academy of Science)
– [[National Geographic Society|NGS]] (National Geographic Society)
– [[World Future Society|WFS]] (World Future Society)
– [[American Association for the Advancement of Science|AAAS]] (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
– [[International PEN|IPC]] (International Pen Club)
– [[Belarusian Association of Journalists|BAJ]] (Belarusian Association of Journalists)
– BATT (Belarusian Association of Think Tanks)
– [[Charter 97]][http://register.consilium.eu.int/pdf/en/01/st09/09000en1.pdf “Report on the fact-finding mission to Belarus”] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140324110829/http://register.consilium.eu.int/pdf/en/01/st09/09000en1.pdf |date=March 24, 2014 }}, ''[[Council of the European Union]]'', June 25, 2001.
– [https://web.archive.org/web/20090406133247/http://belngo.info/cgi-bin/indextesten.pl ADNGOB] (Assembly of Democratic Non-Governmental Organizations of Belarus)
– Chairman of the [http://www.hrights.ru/proj2.htm BHRC] {{Ru icon}} (Belarusian Human Rights Convention)
– Chairman of the Belarusian [[Helsinki Committee for Human Rights|Helsinki]]-XXI
– Coordinating Council of [http://www.sourcewatch.org/index.php?title=Atlantic_Council BEA] (Belarusian Euro-Atlantic Association) ==Science & Publications== His publications would include diverse topics in [[Nuclear physics]], [[cosmology]], [[science history]], [[forecasting]] and many others. * [https://archive.is/20121209103457/http://potupa.iatp.by/articles/1971/r/Ideal_Measur_QFT.htm "Idealized Measuring Procedures in Quantum Theory"] {{Ru icon}} (1970); * [https://archive.is/20121208194753/http://potupa.iatp.by/Beg00DATA.htm "Running to Infinity"] {{Ru icon}} (1977); * [https://archive.is/20121205165205/http://potupa.iatp.by/books.files/nechto/08FantacrimXXItext.htm "Fantacrime – XXI"] {{Ru icon}} (1989); * [https://archive.is/20121206032853/http://potupa.iatp.by/books.files/nechto/14ContactTEXT.htm "Contact, or Some Thoughts & Dialogs heard at Wintry Long Night of the 21st Century"] {{Ru icon}} (1990);[https://www.amazon.com/dp/5704201725 “Kontakt, ili, Neskolko myslei i dialogov, podslushannykh dolgim zimnim vecherom XXI veka”], ''[[Amazon.com|Amazon]]'', 1990. * [https://archive.is/20120713003204/http://potupa.iatp.by/Disc00DATA.htm "Discovery of Universe – Past, Present, Future"] {{Ru icon}} (1991); * [https://archive.is/20121203145822/http://potupa.iatp.by/00NechtoDATA.htm "Something Unimaginable"] {{Ru icon}} (1992)[https://www.amazon.com/dp/585872115X “Nechto nevoobrazimoe: Fantasticheskie povesti i rasskazy”], ''[[Amazon.com|Amazon]]'', 1992. * 5 more books * More than [https://web.archive.org/web/20071208120104/http://potupa.iatp.by/articles.html 200 articles] {{Ru icon}} ==Awards== – [http://www.wow-coupons.com/storage/award_torchbir.jpg Recipient Torch of Birmingham (1995)]
– [http://www.wow-coupons.com/storage/award_intlman98.jpg International Man of Year (Cambridge, England, 1998)]
– [http://www.wow-coupons.com/storage/award_analytical.jpg Best Analytical Material of the Year (BAJ, Minsk, Belarus, 1999)] {{Be icon}}
– [http://www.wow-coupons.com/storage/award_outstanding.jpg Outstanding People of 20th Century (Cambridge, England, 1999)]
– For High Achievements in a Science (IAIT, Minsk, Belarus, 2004)
– For High Achievements in a Science (Gold Medal, IAIT, Minsk, Belarus, 2005) ==Personal Info== – Married, 2 kids
– Wife (Lubov N. Potupa, 1955, manager)
– Daughter ([http://www.wow-coupons.info Elena A. Potoupa], 1975, JD International Law, BS Physics, MBA International Business, President/Owner of Wow Things, Inc., NJ, USA, Internet-"Oscar"-[[Linkshare#LinkShare Golden Link Awards|2005 Golden Link Award]])
– Son (Andrei A. Potupa, 1976, JD International Law, manager, journalist)
– Grandson (Antony, 2002) ==Scholarship== – In 2009, Elena Potoupa, daughter of Alexander S. Potupa, has established the Dr. Alexander S. Potupa Memorial Scholarship[http://view.fdu.edu/default.aspx?id=7480 Dr. Alexander S. Potupa Memorial Scholarship], ''[[Fairleigh Dickinson University]]'', 2009. in memory of her late father, a Belarusian writer, philosopher, scientist and civil activist. The scholarship supports international business students. == References == {{Reflist|2}} == External links == *[https://archive.is/20121209065931/http://potupa.iatp.by/index.html Alexander S. Potupa – Official Web Site] *[http://www.potupa.com Alexander S. Potupa – Personal Web Site] *[http://www.wowdolls.com/asp/en/bio.htm Alexander S. Potupa – Personal Web Site (Old Version)] *[http://slounik.org/80230.html Alexander S. Potupa – "Slounik.org – Belarusian Electronic Encyclopedia"] {{Ru icon}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080317084430/http://dossier.bymedia.net/index.php?Mode=Person&PersonID=731 Alexander S. Potupa – "Press-File of Belarus"] {{Ru icon}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20101207025101/http://who.bdg.by/obj.php?kod=225 Alexander S. Potupa – "Who Is Who in Belarus"] – [https://web.archive.org/web/20090708082502/http://who.bdg.by/all_rtg.php Top 10 Rated!] {{Ru icon}} *[http://www.belarustoday.info/?pid=722 Alexander S. Potupa – "Belarus Today"] {{Ru icon}} *[http://ru.principedia.info/Principedia:Проект:Персоналии Alexander S. Potupa – "Principedia"] {{Ru icon}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090703142659/http://fantasy.open.by/1999102001.html Alexander S. Potupa – "Belarus Sci-Fi Writers"] {{Ru icon}} *[http://fantlab.ru/autor3043 Alexander S. Potupa – "Sci-Fi Fantasy Lab" – full list of books, articles, etc] {{Ru icon}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Potupa, Alexander}} [[Category:1945 births]] [[Category:2009 deaths]] [[Category:Belarusian dissidents]] [[Category:People from Sevastopol]] [[Category:Belarusian scientists]] [[Category:Belarusian physicists]] [[Category:Russian scientists]] [[Category:Russian physicists]] [[Category:Belarusian nuclear physicists]] [[Category:Russian nuclear physicists]] [[Category:Belarusian human rights activists]] [[Category:Belarusian businesspeople]] [[Category:Belarusian economists]] [[Category:Belarusian politicians]] [[Category:Belarusian science fiction writers]] [[Category:Ukrainian science fiction writers]] [[Category:Belarusian people of Ukrainian descent]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = | logo = | type = Subsidiary | traded_as = | foundation = 1994 | location = [[Marlborough, MA]] | key_people = | industry = [[Biotechnology]] | products = Stem cell therapies for macular degeneration (human safety trial started in 2010<ref> {{cite news |title= Company seeks to test stem cells for blindness |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE5AI3GD20091119 |work= Reuters |date=2009-11-25 }}</ref>), retinis pigmentosa, glaucoma and corneal blindness <ref name="advancedcell">{{Cite web |url=https://www.ocata.com/research-development/pipeline-overview |title=Ocata website: Pipeline Overview |access-date=2015-03-09 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150109051134/https://www.ocata.com/research-development/pipeline-overview |archive-date=2015-01-09 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> | homepage = {{Official website|astellas.us/therapeutic/rnd/airm.aspx}} }}
'''Astellas Institute for Regenerative Medicine''' is a subsidiary of [[Astellas Pharma]] located in [[Marlborough, Massachusetts]], developing [[stem cell therapy|stem cell therapies]] with a focus on diseases that cause blindness. It was formed in 1994 as a company named '''Advanced Cell Technology, Incorporated''' ('''ACT'''), which was renamed to '''Ocata Therapeutics''' in November 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://ir.ocata.com/press-releases/detail/2644/advanced-cell-technology-changes-name-to-ocata-therapeutics |title=Advanced Cell Technology Changes Name to Ocata Therapeutics |publisher=Ocata Therapeutics |date=2014-11-14 |accessdate=2015-04-25 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402112607/http://ir.ocata.com/press-releases/detail/2644/advanced-cell-technology-changes-name-to-ocata-therapeutics |archive-date=2015-04-02 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> In February 2016 Ocata acquired by Astellas for $379 million.<ref>http://www.genengnews.com/gen-news-highlights/astellas-to-acquire-ocata-therapeutics-for-379m/81251957/</ref> which was finally completed in February 2016.<ref>http://newsroom.astellas.us/news-releases?item=137160%29.</ref>
==History== Advanced Cell Technology was formed in 1994 and was led from 2005 to late 2010 by William M. Caldwell IV, [[Chairman]] and [[Chief Executive Officer]].<ref>{{cite news |title= Executive Profile | url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=399367&ticker=ACTC:US |work= BusinessWeek.com |date= 23 March 2010 }}</ref> Upon Mr. Caldwell's death on December 13, 2010, Gary Rabin, a member of ACT's board of directors with experience in investment and capital raising, assumed the role of Chairman and CEO.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.advancedcell.com/about-act/leadership-team/senior-executive-officers//| title=Advanced Cell Technology Senior Executive Officers| publisher=Advanced Cell Technology| accessdate=2014-08-13| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140720181139/http://www.advancedcell.com/about-act/leadership-team/senior-executive-officers/| archive-date=2014-07-20| dead-url=yes| df=}}</ref>
In 2007 the company's Chief Scientific Officer (CSO), [[Michael D. West]], PhD, also founder of [[Geron Corporation|Geron]] ({{NASDAQ|GERN}})<ref>{{cite web|title=Bloomberg Longevity Economy Conference 2013 Panelist Bio|url=http://www.bloomberglink.com/people/michael-d-west-ph-d/|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130803060041/http://www.bloomberglink.com/people/michael-d-west-ph-d/|archivedate=2013-08-03|df=}}</ref> left Ocata to join a [[regenerative medicine]] firm, [[BioTime]] ({{NYSE MKT|BTX}}) as [[CEO]]. In 2008, for $250,000 plus royalties up to a total of $1 million, the company licensed its "ACTCellerate" technology to [[BioTime]].<ref>{{cite web |title= Press Release: ACTCellerate Technology Licensed to BioTime, Inc by Advanced Cell Technology |url=http://www.tmcnet.com/usubmit/2008/08/12/3596134.htm}}</ref> [[Robert Lanza]] was appointed CSO.<ref>{{cite news |title= New Method for Controversy Free Embryonic Stem Cells |url=https://www.wired.com/wiredscience/2008/07/a-new-technique |work= Wired Science |date= 9 July 2008 }}</ref>
On November 22, 2010, the company announced that it had received approval from the U.S. [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) to initiate the first human [[clinical trial]] using [[embryonic stem cells]] to treat retinal diseases.<ref>{{cite news |title= FDA approves second human embryonic stem cell trial |url=http://pagingdrgupta.blogs.cnn.com/2010/11/22/fda-approves-second-human-embryonic-stem-cell-trial/ |work= CNN.com |date= 22 November 2010 }}</ref> A preliminary report of the trial published in 2012,<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(12)60028-2 |title=Embryonic stem cell trials for macular degeneration: A preliminary report |journal=The Lancet |volume=379 |issue=9817 |pages=713 |year=2012 |last1=Schwartz |first1=Steven D |last2=Hubschman |first2=Jean-Pierre |last3=Heilwell |first3=Gad |last4=Franco-Cardenas |first4=Valentina |last5=Pan |first5=Carolyn K |last6=Ostrick |first6=Rosaleen M |last7=Mickunas |first7=Edmund |last8=Gay |first8=Roger |last9=Klimanskaya |first9=Irina |last10=Lanza |first10=Robert }}</ref> and a follow-up article was published in February 2015.<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(14)61376-3 |title=Human embryonic stem cell-derived retinal pigment epithelium in patients with age-related macular degeneration and Stargardt's macular dystrophy: Follow-up of two open-label phase 1/2 studies |journal=The Lancet |volume=385 |issue=9967 |pages=509 |year=2015 |last1=Schwartz |first1=Steven D |last2=Regillo |first2=Carl D |last3=Lam |first3=Byron L |last4=Eliott |first4=Dean |last5=Rosenfeld |first5=Philip J |last6=Gregori |first6=Ninel Z |last7=Hubschman |first7=Jean-Pierre |last8=Davis |first8=Janet L |last9=Heilwell |first9=Gad |last10=Spirn |first10=Marc |last11=Maguire |first11=Joseph |last12=Gay |first12=Roger |last13=Bateman |first13=Jane |last14=Ostrick |first14=Rosaleen M |last15=Morris |first15=Debra |last16=Vincent |first16=Matthew |last17=Anglade |first17=Eddy |last18=Del Priore |first18=Lucian V |last19=Lanza |first19=Robert }}</ref>
In July 2014, Ocata announced that Paul K. Wotton, previously of Antares Pharma Inc (ATRS:NASDAQ CM), became President and Chief Executive Officer.<ref>http://www.marketwatch.com/story/advanced-cell-technology-appoints-paul-k-wotton-phd-president-and-chief-executive-officer-2014-06-24{{full|date=September 2018}}</ref>
On August 27, 2014, Ocata announced a 1-100 reverse stock split of its common stock.<ref>https://online.wsj.com/article/PR-CO-20140827-918716.html{{full|date=September 2018}}</ref> Ocata was listed on [[NASDAQ]] in February 2015.<ref>[http://markets.on.nytimes.com/research/stocks/news/press_release.asp?docTag=201502260902BIZWIRE_USPRX____BW5085&feedID=600&press_symbol=38044 Ocata Therapeutics Approved for Listing on NASDAQ February 26, 2015]</ref>
==Research==
=== Macular degeneration === On November 30, 2010, Ocata filed an [[Investigational New Drug]] application with the U.S. FDA for the first [[clinical trial]] using [[embryonic stem cells]] to regenerate [[retinal pigment epithelium]] to treat Dry Age-Related [[Macular Degeneration]] (Dry AMD).<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://advancedcell.com/news-and-media/press-releases/advanced-cell-technology-files-ind-with-fda-for-first-clinical-trial-using-embryonic-stem-cells-to-tr/ |title=Advanced Cell Technology Files IND with FDA for First Clinical Trial Using Embryonic Stem Cells to Treat Dry AMD. |access-date=2010-11-30 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101205080223/http://www.advancedcell.com/news-and-media/press-releases/advanced-cell-technology-files-ind-with-fda-for-first-clinical-trial-using-embryonic-stem-cells-to-tr/ |archive-date=2010-12-05 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> Dry AMD is the most common form of [[macular degeneration]] and represents a market size of $25–30 Billion in the U.S. and [[Europe]].<ref>[http://www.wbjournal.com/news47863.html ACT Seeks FDA Approval For Stem Cell Study.]</ref>
=== Stargardt's disease === In November 2010 the FDA allowed Ocata to begin a Phase I/II human [[clinical trial]] to use its [[retinal pigment epithelium]] cell therapy to treat [[Stargardt disease]], a form of inherited juvenile [[macular degeneration]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Advanced Cell Technology Receives FDA Clearance to Initiate Clinical Trials|url=http://retinatoday.com/2011/01/advanced-cell-technology-receives-fda-clearance-to-initiate-clinical-trials|website=Retina Today|accessdate=5 April 2015}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Stem cell#Key research events|Key stem cell research events]] * [[Somatic cell nuclear transfer]] * [[Stem cell controversy#Stem cells without embryonic destruction|Stem cells without embryonic destruction]] * [[Michael D. West]] * [[Geron Corporation]] * [[BioTime]]
== References == {{reflist}}

revision.text:
[[File:Autographic Register.jpg|thumb|right|Autographic Register - National Cash Register Company, 1898]] An '''Autographic Register''' is a business machine invented in 1883 by James C. Shoup. The device consisted two separate rolls of paper interleaved with [[carbon paper]]. Usually one or both of the rolls would be preprinted with form information. To operate the machine the user would write, for example, a sales receipt and the machine automatically produced a copy. The crank on the machine ejected the records and moved a blank form into view. The original receipt produced would go to the user and the copy was filed.<ref name=BusRef>{{cite web|title=Standard Register Co.|url=http://www.referenceforbusiness.com/history2/4/Standard-Register-Co.html|website=Reference for Business|accessdate=June 14, 2015}}</ref> Shoup founded the Autographic Register Company in [[Hoboken, NJ]] to manufacture his invention.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://hoboken.pastperfectonline.com/bysearchterm?keyword=Autographic+Register+Company|website=Hoboken Historical Museum Online Collections Database|title=Autographic Register Company|accessdate=June 14, 2015}}</ref>
The Autographic Register was an advance over use of separate forms and carbon paper as it guaranteed that the copy was made and kept the forms in relative alignment. A number of advancements were soon made, including the use of sprocket-fed paper, invented by Theodore Schirmer. This helped avoid slippage and misalignment of forms, allowing more copies to be produced simultaneously. In 1912 Schirmer founded the [[Standard Register Industrial|Standard Register Company]] in [[Dayton, Ohio]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Standard Register|title=100 Years of Innovation|url=http://media.standardregister.com/standard-register/docs/company/Centennial-Whitepaper.pdf|accessdate=June 14, 2015}}</ref>
The invention of sprocket-fed paper later found use in computer printers.
Although the Autographic Register has been largely replaced by newer technology it remains in use as of 2015.<ref>{{cite web|title=Portable Register - Plastic Register for 4 x 6 Forms|url=https://www.deluxe.com/shopdeluxe/pd/portable-register-plastic-register-for-4-x-6-forms/_/A-D924|website=Deluxe Enterprise Operations|accessdate=June 14, 2015}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox officeholder |name = Cameron Kerry |image = Cameron Kerry official portrait.jpeg |office = [[United States Secretary of Commerce]]
{{small|Acting}} |president = [[Barack Obama]] |deputy = [[Patrick D. Gallagher]] {{small|(Acting)}} |term_start = June 1, 2013 |term_end = June 26, 2013 |predecessor = [[Rebecca Blank]] |successor = [[Penny Pritzker]] |birth_name=Cameron Forbes Kerry |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1950|9|6}} |birth_place = [[Washington, D.C.]], [[United states|U.S.]] |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] |parents = [[Richard Kerry]]
[[Rosemary Forbes Kerry|Rosemary Forbes]] |relations = See [[Forbes family]] |alma_mater = [[Harvard University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|A.B.]])
[[Boston College]] ([[Juris Doctor|J.D.]]) }} '''Cameron Forbes Kerry''' (born September 6, 1950) is an American politician who served as general counsel of the [[US Department of Commerce|U.S. Department of Commerce]]. He is the younger brother and political confidant of [[John Kerry|John Forbes Kerry]], former [[List of United States Senators from Massachusetts|Massachusetts Senator]], [[United States presidential election, 2004|2004]] presidential nominee, and former [[U.S. Secretary of State]].{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/cameron-f-kerry/gIQAaEPEAP_topic.html|work=The Washington Post|title=Cameron F. Kerry|date=July 25, 2012}} Kerry was appointed Acting [[United States Secretary of Commerce]] on June 1, 2013,{{cite web |url=http://www.commerce.gov/about-commerce/commerce-leadership/cameron-kerry |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-06-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130602154603/http://www.commerce.gov/about-commerce/commerce-leadership/cameron-kerry |archivedate=2013-06-02 |df= }} and resumed his position as general counsel on June 26, 2013, when [[Penny Pritzker]] was sworn in as the 38th [[United States Secretary of Commerce|Secretary of Commerce]]. As the General Counsel of the Department of Commerce, Kerry was the principal legal advisor to the Secretary of Commerce and third ranking secretarial officer. He resigned his position on September 4, 2013.{{cite web|title=Cameron F. Kerry|url=https://ogc.commerce.gov/directory/cameronfkerry|website=Office of the Chief Counsel|publisher=Department of Commerce|accessdate=29 January 2018}} ==Early life== Cameron Forbes Kerry was born on September 6, 1950 in [[Washington, D.C.]]. He is the fourth child of U.S. diplomat [[Richard Kerry|Richard John Kerry]] and [[Rosemary Forbes Kerry|Rosemary Isabel Forbes]] of the [[Forbes family]] and Dudley–Winthrop family. He graduated from [[Harvard College]] in 1972, and [[Boston College Law School]] in 1978. ==Career== After graduation from law school, Kerry was an associate with [[Wilmer Cutler Pickering Hale and Dorr]] in Washington, D.C. and served as law clerk to U.S. Senior Circuit Judge [[Elbert Tuttle]], former Chief Judge of the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit]] (now the Eleventh Circuit). He has been an Adjunct Professor of Telecommunications Law at [[Suffolk University Law School]] and has written on First Amendment and cable television issues.{{cite web|url=http://www.mintz.com/people.php?BioID=196|title=Mintz Levin Cohn Ferris Glovsky and Popeo Biography}} From 1983 to 2008, he worked as a partner at [[Mintz, Levin, Cohn, Ferris, Glovsky, and Popeo]], focusing on civil litigation, environmental issues, and communications regulation.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} In 1983, Cameron Kerry [[Conversion to Judaism|converted]] from Roman Catholicism to [[Judaism]] before marrying Kathy Weinman.{{cite web|url=http://www.jta.org/page_view_story.asp?intarticleid=13768&intcategoryid=5|title=Cameron Kerry and his in-laws talk of the Democratic frontrunner|work=Detroit Jewish News|accessdate=2006-08-27|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061114113112/http://www.jta.org/page_view_story.asp?intarticleid=13768&intcategoryid=5#|archive-date=2006-11-14|dead-url=yes|df=}} Cameron Kerry traveled across the country speaking to his brother's views on Israel, campaigning with [[Harvard Law School]] professor [[Alan Dershowitz]], writer-comedian [[Larry David]], and Jewish elected officials.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2004/oct/29/entertainment/et-jewish29|title=Kerry's entree to Jewish vote|work=Los Angeles Times|first=Johanna|last=Neuman|date=October 29, 2004}} In 2004, Cameron Kerry served as an influential advisor in his brother's presidential campaign. Kerry played a role in decisions behind the scenes and as a campaign surrogate.{{cite news | url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A03E7D9163DF936A25751C0A9629C8B63&n=Top%2FNews%2FWashington%2FCampaign%202004%2FCandidates%2FJohn%20F%20Kerry|title=THE 2004 CAMPAIGN: THE CONFIDANT; Kerry Turns to His Brother For Help on Big Decisions|work=New York Times|first=Timothy L.|last=O'Brien|date=February 15, 2004|accessdate=April 28, 2010}} In 2006, Cameron Kerry explored a run for Massachusetts Secretary of the Commonwealth but decided not to run when the Democratic incumbent [[William F. Galvin]] announced that he would seek re-election.{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/articles/2005/07/27/kerrys_brother_mulls_a_run|title=Kerry's brother mulls a run|work=Boston Globe|first=Frank|last=Phillips|date=July 27, 2005}} During the 2008 Presidential campaign, he was the Vice-Chair of the [[National Jewish Democratic Council]] and defended [[Barack Obama]] in the Jewish press.{{cite web|url=http://jta.org/news/article/2008/04/18/108170/kerryobama|title=Obama is calling to Jews|work=Jewish Telegraphic Agency (JTA)|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120509235259/http://www.jta.org/news/article/2008/04/18/108170/kerryobama|archivedate=2012-05-09|df=}} On April 20, 2009, President Obama nominated him, and on May 21, 2009, he was confirmed unanimously by the United States Senate as the General Counsel of the Department of Commerce. In this role, Kerry was the principal legal advisor to the Secretary of Commerce and third ranking secretarial officer. He served as the department's chief legal officer and oversees the work of over 325 lawyers in 14 offices. Kerry also serves as the department's chief ethics officer, and co-chairs the secretary's Internet Policy Task Force, which brings together Commerce agencies with expertise on the internet in the 21st-century global economy.[http://www.commerce.gov/os/ogc/profiles/cameron-f-kerry Profile], commerce.gov; accessed August 5, 2015. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{commons category}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[Rebecca Blank]]
{{small|Acting}}}} {{s-ttl|title=[[United States Secretary of Commerce]]
{{small|Acting}}|years=2013}} {{s-aft|after=[[Penny Pritzker]]}} {{s-end}} {{John Kerry}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Kerry, Cameron}} [[Category:1950 births]] [[Category:Boston College Law School alumni]] [[Category:Forbes family]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Massachusetts Democrats]] [[Category:Massachusetts lawyers]] [[Category:Kerry family]] [[Category:Obama administration cabinet members]] [[Category:21st-century American politicians]] [[Category:Politicians from Boston]] [[Category:United States Secretaries of Commerce]] [[Category:Dudley–Winthrop family]] [[Category:Woolsey family]] [[Category:Politicians from Washington, D.C.]] [[Category:Mintz Levin partners]] [[Category:Wilmer Cutler Pickering Hale and Dorr associates]]
