revision.text:
[[File:IsaKidd copper refinery.png|thumb|A modern copper refinery tankhouse using IsaKidd technology.]]
The '''IsaKidd Technology''' is a [[copper]] [[electrorefining]] and [[electrowinning]] technology that was developed independently by Copper Refineries Proprietary Limited (“CRL”), a [[Townsville]], [[Queensland]] subsidiary of [[MIM Holdings Limited]] (which is now part of the [[Glencore]] group of companies), and at the [[Falconbridge Ltd.|Falconbridge Limited]] (“Falconbridge”) now-dismantled Kidd Creek refinery that was at [[Timmins]], [[Ontario]]. It is based around the use of reusable [[cathode]] starter sheets for [[copper]] electrorefining and the automated stripping of the deposited “cathode copper” from them.<ref name = "Jenkins">J C Jenkins, “Copper tank house technology reviewed and assessed,” in: ''The Aus.I.M.M. North Queensland Branch, Smelting and Refining Operators Symposium, May 1985'' (The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy: Melbourne, 1985), 195–204.</ref>
==Introduction==
The current IsaKidd technology represents the merger of the copper refining technologies developed by the two different organisations. The initial '''Isa Process''' development in the late 1970s, with its reusable stainless-steel cathode starter sheets, represented an advance on the previous technology of single-use starter sheets of pure copper,<ref name = "Jenkins"/> the production of which was a labour-intensive process.
The production of the single-use starter sheets involved laying down a sheet of copper by electrolysis on each side of a “mother plate”.<ref name = "Jenkins"/> Generating the sheet took a day, and thousands of sheets could be needed every day.<ref name = "Jenkins"/> Originally, the copper starter sheets were separated from the mother plate manually, but over time the process was automated.<ref name = "Jenkins"/><ref name = "Nakai">O Nakai, H Sato, K Kugiyama and K Baba, “A new starting sheet plant at the Toyo copper refinery and productivity improvements,” in: ''Proceedings of Copper 99–Cobre 99 International Conference, Volume III—Electrorefining and Electrowinning of Copper'', Eds J E Dutrizac, J Ji and V Ramachandran (The Minerals, Metals and Materials Society: Warrendale, Pennsylvania, 1999), 279–289.</ref> In addition, limitations associated with the use of copper starter sheets meant that it was difficult to meet the purity specifications of some new copper applications that were, in the 1970s and 1980s, demanding higher quality copper.
The development of the Isa Process tank house technology at CRL eliminated the whole process and cost of producing the starter sheets by using [[Stainless steel|stainless-steel]] permanent cathodes.<ref name = "Jenkins"/> It also included substantial automation of the process of inserting the permanent cathodes into the electrolytic cells and their subsequent removal and stripping of the sheets of deposited cathode copper.<ref name = "Jenkins"/> The labour force required to operate a refinery using the IsaKidd technology has been estimated at 60–70% less of that required for refineries using starter sheets.<ref name = "Armstrong">W Armstrong, “The Isa Process and its contribution to electrolytic copper,” paper presented at the ''Rautomead Conference, Scotland, August 1999''.</ref><ref name = "Hopkins">W R Hopkins and I E Lewis, “Recent innovations in SX/EW plants to reduce capital and operating costs,” ''Minerals & Metallurgical Processing'', February 1990, 1–8.</ref>
MIM Holdings began marketing the Isa Process technology in 1980, as a result of demand from other refinery operators.
Falconbridge subsequently independently developed a similar process to improve operations at its Kidd Creek copper refinery, near [[Timmins]], [[Ontario]].<ref name = "About">[http://www.isaprocess.com/EN/AboutIsaKiddTechnology/Pages/AboutIsaKiddTechnology.aspx “About ISAKIDD Technology.”] Accessed 20 June 2013.</ref> The initial development of permanent cathodes was for internal use, but marketing of the '''Kidd Process''' was initiated in 1992 after requests from other refinery operators.<ref name = "Donaldson99">P E Donaldson and P J Murphy, “Kidd Process permanent cathode technology advancements,” in: ''Proceedings of [sic] Copper 99–Cobre 99 International Conference. Volume III—Electrorefining and Electrowinning of Copper'', Eds J E Dutrizac, J Ji and V Ramachandran (The Minerals, Metals and Materials Society: Warrendale, Pennsylvania, 1999) 301–310.</ref>
The two technologies were brought together as the IsaKidd Technology in 2006, when Xstrata bought Falconbridge.<ref name = "About"/>
The IsaKidd Technology now dominates global copper refining. It has been licensed to 102 users and Xstrata Technology, which markets the technology, reports on its website a total installed capacity of some 12 million tonnes per year (“t/y”) of copper production, as of October 2011.<ref name = "Installations">[http://www.isakidd.com/EN/Installations/Pages/Installations.aspx List of IsaKidd installations.] Accessed 20 June 2013.</ref> This is about 60% of the estimated 2011 global refined copper production of 19.7 million tonnes.<ref>[http://www.icsg.org/index.php/component/jdownloads/finish/170/1188 ''The World Copper Factbook 2012''], International Copper Study Group. Accessed 29 June 2013.</ref>
The development of the IsaKidd technology allowed increased productivity, reduced operating costs and the production of consistent, high-quality cathode copper.<ref name = "Armstrong"/>
==History of the Development of the IsaKidd Technology==
===The old way of electrorefining copper (pre-1978)===
The process of electrorefining copper consists of placing a copper [[anode]] (about 99.5–99.7% pure copper<ref name = "Armstrong"/><ref name = "Robinson"/>) in [[sulfuric acid]], together with a cathode, and passing a current between the anode and cathode through an external circuit.<ref name = "Robinson">T Robinson, “Electrolytic refining,” in: ''Extractive Metallurgy of Copper, Fourth Edition'', Eds W G Davenport, M King, M Schlesinger and A K Biswas (Elsevier Science Limited: Kidlington, Oxford, England, 2002) 265–288.</ref> At the applied [[Galvanic series|electropotential]], copper and less [[Noble metal|noble]] elements dissolve in the [[electrolyte]], while elements more noble than copper, such as [[gold]] and [[silver]], do not.<ref name = "Robinson"/> Under the influence of the applied [[Electric potential|electrical potential]], copper ions migrate from the anode and deposit on the cathode, forming cathode copper.<ref name = "Robinson"/>
Electrolytic refining of copper was first patented in England by James Elkington in 1865 and the first electrolytic copper refinery was built in Newark, New Jersey, in 1883.<ref name = "Armstrong"/>
There were teething problems with the new technology. For example, the early refineries had trouble producing firm deposits on the cathodes.<ref name = "Armstrong"/> As a result, there was much secrecy between refinery operators as each strove to maintain a competitive edge.<ref name = "Armstrong"/>
The nature of the cathode used to collect the copper is a critical part of the technology. The properties of copper are highly susceptible to impurities. For example, an arsenic content of 0.1% can reduce the conductivity of copper by 23% and a bismuth content of just 0.001% makes copper brittle.<ref name = "Lynch">D C Lynch, S Akagi and W G Davenport, “Thermochemical nature of minor elements in copper smelting mattes,” ''Metallurgical Transactions B'', 22B, October 1991, 677–688.</ref> The material used in the cathode must not contaminate the copper being deposited, or it will not meet the required specifications.
The current efficiency of the refining process depends, in part, on how close the anodes and cathodes can be placed in the electrolytic cell. This, in turn, depends on the straightness of both the anode and the cathode. Bumps and bends in either can lead to short-circuiting or otherwise affect the current distribution and also the quality of the cathode copper.<ref name = "Robinson"/>
[[File:Rack of copper cathode starter sheets.png|thumb|Figure 1. A crane carrying a rack of starter sheet cathode.]] Prior to the development of the Isa Process technology, the standard approach was to use a starter sheet of high-purity copper as the initial cathode.<ref name = "Jenkins"/> These starter sheets are produced in special electrolytic cells by electrodeposition of copper for 24 hours<ref name = "Armstrong"/> onto a plate made of copper coated with oil<ref name = "Jenkins"/> (or treated with other similar face-separation materials) or of [[titanium]].<ref name = "Armstrong"/> Thousands of sheets could be needed every day,<ref name = "Nakai"/> and the original method of separating the starter sheet from the “mother plate” (referred to as “stripping”) was entirely manual.<ref name = "Jenkins"/>
Starter sheets are usually quite light. For example, the starter sheets used in the CRL refinery weighed 10 pounds (4.53 kilograms).<ref name = "Saint">J C Jenkins and J C Saint-Smith, “Townsville copper refinery,” ''Proceedings of the Aus.I.M.M.'', No. 197, 1961, 239–260.</ref> Thus, they are thin and need to be handled carefully to avoid bending.
[[File:Copper cathode from copper starter sheets.png|thumb|Figure 2. Cathode copper deposited on copper starter sheets.]] Over time, the formation of starter sheets was improved by mechanisation, but there was still a high labour input.<ref name = "Jenkins"/>
Once the starter sheets were formed, they had to be flattened, to reduce the likelihood of short circuits, and then cut, formed and punched to make loops from which the starter sheets are hung from conductive copper hanger bars in the electrolytic cells (see Figure 1).<ref name = "Armstrong"/>
The starter sheets are inserted in the refining cells and dissolved copper deposits on them to produce the cathode copper product (see Figure 2). Because of the manufacturing cost of the starter sheets, refineries using them tend to keep them in the cells as long as possible, usually 12–14 days.<ref name = "Armstrong"/> On the other hand, the anodes normally reside in the cells for 24–28 days, meaning that there are two cathodes produced from each anode.<ref name = "Armstrong"/>
The starter sheets have a tendency to warp, due to the mechanical stresses they encounter and often need to be removed from the refining cells after about two days to be straightened in presses before being returned to the cells.<ref name = "Schlesinger">M E Schlesinger, M J King, K C Sole and W G Davenport, Extractive Metallurgy of Copper, Fifth Edition (Elsevier: 2011), 259.</ref> The tendency to warp leads to frequent short-circuiting.<ref name = "Schlesinger"/>
Due to their limitations, it is difficult for copper produced on starter sheets to meet modern specifications for the highest-purity copper.<ref name = "Donaldson">P E Donaldson and J J Detulleo, “Falconbridge’s Kidd Copper Refinery – birthplace of the Kidd Process: an update on the refinery and the latest developments in the Kidd Process”, in: ''Copper 2003–Cobre 2003. Volume V — Copper Electrorefining and Electrowinning, Santiago, Chile, 30 November–3 December 2003'', Eds: J E Dutrizac and C G Clement (Canadian Institute of Mining, Metallurgy and Petroleum: Montreal, 2003), 165–174.</ref>
===The development of the Isa Process technology===
The development of the Isa Process tank house technology had its beginning in the zinc industry.<ref name = "Armstrong"/> During the mid-1970s, MIM Holdings Limited (“MIM”) was considering building a zinc refinery in Townsville to treat the zinc concentrate produced by its [[Mount Isa]] operations.<ref name = "Armstrong"/> As a result, MIM staff visited the zinc smelters using the best-practice technology and found that modern electrolytic zinc smelters had adopted permanent cathode plate and mechanised stripping technology.<ref name = "Armstrong"/>
MIM recognised that the performance of traditional copper refineries was constrained by the poor cathode geometry inherent in using copper starter sheets.<ref>N J Aslin, D Stone and W Webb, [http://www.isakidd.com/EN/Downloads/Technical%20Papers/Current%20Distribution%20in%20Modern%20Copper%20Refining.pdf. “Current distribution in modern copper refining,”] in: ''Proceedings of the International Symposium on Computational Analysis'', Eds M J Dry and D G Dixon (Canadian Institute of Mining, Metallurgy and Petroleum: 2005). Accessed 23 May 2013.</ref>
MIM then developed a research program aimed at developing similar permanent cathode technology for copper refining.<ref name = "Armstrong"/> CRL had been operating in Townsville since 1959,<ref name = "Saint"/> using conventional starter-sheet technology<ref name = "Jenkins"/> and treating [[Copper extraction techniques#Converting|blister copper]] produced in the [[Mount Isa Mines]] Limited copper smelter at [[Mount Isa]] in Queensland.<ref name = "Saint"/> CRL incorporated the permanent cathode technology in its 1978 refinery modernisation project.<ref name = "Jenkins"/><ref name = "Armstrong"/> The material initially selected was [[SAE steel grades#Stainless steel|316L]] stainless steel,<ref name = "Aslin">N J Aslin, O Eriksson, G J Heferen and G Sue Yek, [http://www.isakidd.com/EN/Downloads/Technical%20Papers/Developments%20in%20Cathode%20Stripping%20Machines%20-%20An%20Integrated%20Approach%20for%20Improved%20Efficiency.pdf “Developments in cathode stripping machines – an integrated approach for improved efficiency,”] in: ''Proceedings of Cu 2010, Hamburg, Germany, 6–10 June 2010''. Accessed 23 May 2013.</ref> stitch-welded to a [[SAE steel grades#Stainless steel|304L]] stainless-steel hanger bar.<ref name = "Webb">W Webb and J Weston, [http://www.isakidd.com/EN/Downloads/Technical%20Papers/developments_in_steel_cathodes1.pdf “The development of a “lower resistance” permanent cathode (ISA Cathode BR),”] Minera Chilena, March–April 2003. Accessed 28 June 2013.</ref> The hanger-bar assembly was then electroplated with copper to a thickness of 1.3 millimeters (“mm”) (later increased to 2.5 mm and then 3.0 mm to improve the corrosion resistance of the hanger bar) to approximately 15 mm down onto the blade, which provided sufficient electrical conductivity and gave the assembly some corrosion resistance.<ref name = "Webb"/>
Electrodeposited copper adheres quite firmly to the stainless steel so that it does not detach during refining.<ref name = "Schlesinger"/> The vertical edges of the stainless steel plates are covered with tight-fitting polymer edge strips to prevent copper depositing around the edge of the cathode plate and so make it easier to strip the cathode copper from them.<ref name = "Schlesinger"/> The bottom of the cathode plates were masked with a thin film of wax, again to prevent the copper depositing around the bottom edge.<ref name = "Armstrong"/> Wax was used rather than an edge strip to avoid having a ledge that would collect falling anode slimes and contaminate the cathode copper.<ref name = "Armstrong"/>
Wax was also used on the vertical edges to prolong the life of the vertical edge strip.<ref name = "Armstrong"/>
The original cathode stripping machine was based on that used at the Hikoshima plant of the [[Mitsui Mining & Smelting|Mitsui Mining and Smelting Company]] of [[Japan]].<ref name = "Armstrong"/> However, considerable development work was necessary to modify the design to handle the copper cathodes, which were heavier than those at Hikoshima, and to process the cathode plates without damaging them.<ref name = "Armstrong"/> The machines also had to be redesigned to allow for waxing the sides and bottoms of the cathode plates to allow the next copper cathode sheets to be removed easily.<ref name = "Armstrong"/>
[[File:Isa Process cathode stripping machine.png|thumb|Figure 3. An IsaProcess automated cathode stripping machine.]] The stripping machines included receiving and discharge conveyors, washing, separation, cathode stacking and discharging, cathode plate separation for refurbishing, and the wax applications for the sides and bottoms of the cathode plates.<ref name = "Hopkins"/>
The original CRL stripping machine had the capability of stripping 250 cathode plates per hour.<ref name = "Armstrong"/>
The lower cost of the cathode plates compared to starter sheets means that shorter cathode cycle times are possible.<ref name = "Armstrong"/> The cycle time can range from 5 to 14 days, but a seven-day cathode cycle is common.<ref name = "Armstrong"/> This shorter cycle time improves current efficiency as less short circuits occur and there is less nodulation of the cathode surface.<ref name = "Armstrong"/>
Initially, other refinery operators regarded the developments at CRL with scepticism.<ref name = "Jenkins"/> Stainless steel had been tried unsuccessfully as mother-plate material for copper starter sheets.<ref name = "Jenkins"/> They suffered from rapid deterioration of their strippability, resulting in “an almost daily increase in difficulty of stripping”.<ref name = "Jenkins"/> However, following the success of early installations in Townsville, Timmins, and many other places, the permanent stainless steel cathode technology has had widespread introduction.<ref name = "Schlesinger"/>
===Moving into electrowinning plants===
The Isa Process was originally developed for the CRL copper electrorefinery in Townsville. It was subsequently licensed to the [[Copper Range Company]] for its [[Copper Range Company#White Pine mine|White Pine]] copper refinery.<ref name = "Installations"/>
The next licence issued was for an electrowinning application at the [[Port Pirie#History|Broken Hill Associated Smelters]] (“BHAS”) lead smelter at [[Port Pirie]], in [[South Australia]]. BHAS commissioned in 1985 a solvent extraction and electrowinning (“SX–EW”) to recover copper from copper–lead matte produced as a by-product of the lead smelting operations.<ref name = "Meadows">N E Meadows and M Valenti, “The BHAS copper–lead matte treatment plant,” in: ''Non-ferrous Smelting Symposium, Port Pirie, South Australia, September 1989'' (The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy: Melbourne, 1989), 153–157.</ref> The process used involves leaching the copper from the material using an acidic chloride–sulfate solution, followed by solvent extraction to concentrate the leached copper and electrowinning.<ref name = "Tyson">R K Tyson, N E Meadows and A D Pavlich, “Copper production from matte at Pasminco Metals — BHAS, Port Pirie, SA,” in: ''Australasian Mining and Metallurgy. The Sir Maurice Mawby Memorial Volume, Second Edition, Volume 1'', Eds J T Woodcock and J K Hamilton (The Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy: Melbourne, 1993), 732–734.</ref>
[[Electrowinning]] copper differs from electrorefining in that electrorefining uses a copper anode that is dissolved and redeposited on the cathode, while in electrowinning the copper is already in solution and is extracted from the solution by passing a current through the solution using an inert lead-alloy anode, and a cathode.<ref name = "Robinson2">T Robinson, “Electrowinning,” in: ''Extractive Metallurgy of Copper, Fourth Edition'', Eds W G Davenport, M King, M Schlesinger and A K Biswas (Elsevier Science Limited: Kidlington, Oxford, England, 2002) 327–339.</ref>
The chloride in the leach solution at Port Pirie proved to be a problem for the stainless steel cathodes of the Isa Process.<ref name = "Meadows"/> A small amount of the chloride ions in the leach solution passed through the solvent into the electrolyte, leading to a reported chloride concentration of 80 milligrams per liter (“mg/L”) in the electrolyte.<ref name = "Meadows"/> The presence of the chloride in the electrolyte caused pitting corrosion of the stainless steel cathode plates.<ref name = "Meadows"/> After trying other types of stainless steel,<ref name = "Meadows"/> BHAS switched to using titanium cathode plates.<ref name = "Tyson"/>
Other electrowinning operations followed, including [[Ross H. Stanfield|Gibraltar Mines]]’ [[McLeese Lake, British Columbia|McLeese Lake]] operation and Magma Copper’s [[San Manuel copper mine]] in 1986, the Mexicana de [[Cananea]] operation in Mexico in 1989, and the Gunpowder Copper Limited operation at Gunpowder in north-west Queensland 1990.<ref name = "Installations"/> These operations did not suffer the chloride corrosion problems experienced by BHAS.
===The development of the Kidd Process technology===
[[Falconbridge Limited]] in mid-1981 commissioned a copper smelter and refinery near Timmins, Ontario, to treat concentrate from its [[Kidd Mine]].<ref>C J Newman, G Macfarlane and K Molnar, “Oxygen usage in the Kidd Creek smelter,” in: ''The Impact of Oxygen on the Productivity of Non-ferrous Metallurgical Processes, Winnipeg, Canada, 23–26 August 1987'', Eds G Kachaniwsky and C Newman (Pergamon Press: Toronto, 1987), 259–268.</ref> However, at the outset, the quality of the cathode copper produced in the Kidd refinery suffered from the presence of higher than usual concentrations of lead and selenium in the copper smelter’s anodes.<ref name = "Donaldson99"/> Kidd cathode copper was not able to meet its customers’ specifications and obtaining product certification for the [[London Metal Exchange]] (“LME”) became a key focus.<ref name = "Donaldson99"/>
After several process improvements were instigated, it was ultimately realised that the use of copper starter sheets was preventing the Kidd refinery meeting its cathode quality targets.<ref name = "Donaldson99"/> Test work then began on the use of permanent stainless-steel cathodes.<ref name = "Donaldson99"/> Preliminary tests using full-scale titanium blanks showed a reduction in the lead content of the cathode copper of a factor of four and a six-fold reduction in the selenium content, compared with the use of copper starter sheets.<ref name = "Donaldson99"/>
The focus then shifted to developing a stripping machine, to develop stainless steel cathodes incorporating the existing header bars and evaluating edge-strip technology.<ref name = "Donaldson99"/> The company’s board of directors gave approval for the conversion of the refinery to the Kidd technology in April 1985.<ref name = "Donaldson99"/> The conversion was completed in 1986<ref name = "Donaldson99"/> and the Kidd refinery became the third<ref name = "Installations"/> to install permanent cathode and automated stripping technology.
Falconbridge began marketing the technology in 1992, after many requests from other refinery operators.<ref name = "About"/> Thus, the Kidd Process created competition between two suppliers of permanent cathode technology. The main differences between them were the cathode header bar, edge stripping and the stripping machine technology.<ref>W G Davenport, “Copper extraction from the 60’s into the 21st century,” in: ''Proceedings of [sic] Copper 99–Cobre 99 International Conference. Volume I—Plenary Lectures/Movement of Copper and Industry Outlook/Copper Applications and Fabrication'', Ed G A Eltringham, N L Piret and M Sahoo (The Minerals, Metals and Materials Society: Warrendale, Pennsylvania, 1999), 55–79.</ref>
In contrast to the stainless steel header bar then used in the Isa Process cathode, the Kidd Process cathode used a solid copper header bar, which was welded onto the stainless steel sheet.<ref name = "Donaldson"/> This gave a lower voltage drop (by 8–10 millivolts) than the Isa Process cathode.<ref name = "Donaldson"/>
The Isa Process technology used the waxed edge at the bottom of the cathode plate to stop the copper depositing around the plate’s bottom to form a single mass of copper running from the top of one side of the cathode plate around the bottom to the top of the other side.<ref name = "Aslin"/> The copper was stripped from the cathode plates as two separate sheets.<ref name = "Aslin"/> The Kidd Process technology did not use wax, as it was thought that it could exacerbate the impurity problems with which the plant had been struggling. At Kidd, the stripping approach was to remove the copper from the cathode plate as a single “V”-shaped cathode product, akin to a taco shell.<ref name = "Aslin"/>
The Kidd Process initially used a “carousel” stripping machine, but a linear installation was subsequently developed to provide machines with lower to medium stripping capacities for electrowinning plants and smaller refineries.<ref name = "Donaldson"/> The linear stripping machines, first installed in 1996, were more compact, less complex and had lower installation costs than the carousel machines.<ref name = "Donaldson"/>
===New advances===
====Waxless cathode plates====
As outlined above, the Kidd Process did not use wax on its permanent cathodes.<ref name = "Armstrong"/> This highlighted disadvantages associated with the use of wax by the Isa Process.<ref name = "Armstrong"/> Cathode copper consumers applied pressure to producers to remove residual wax from the cathode copper, and the use of wax also created “housekeeping” problems for Isa Process operators.<ref name = "Armstrong"/>
Consequently, MIM commenced a development program in 1997 aimed at eliminating the use of wax.<ref name = "Armstrong"/> This resulted in a new process called the Isa 2000 technology, which was able to produce single-sheet cathode (as opposed to the Kidd taco shell cathode) without using wax.<ref name = "Armstrong"/>
[[File:Cathode starter sheet V-groove.png|thumb|Figure 4. Effect of the V-groove at the bottom edge of the cathode starting plate on the deposited cathode copper.]] This was achieved by machining a 90° “V”-groove into the bottom edge of the cathode.<ref name = "Eastwood">K L Eastwood and G W Whebell, [http://www.isakidd.com/EN/Downloads/Technical%20Papers/developments_in_steel_cathodes1.pdf. “Developments in permanent stainless steel cathodes within the copper industry,”] in: ''Proceedings of the Sixth International Copper–Cobre Conference, Toronto, Canada, 25–30 August 2007. Volume V—Copper Electrorefining and Electrowinning'' (The Canadian Institute of Mining, Metallurgy and Petroleum: 2007), 35–46. Accessed 23 May 2013.</ref> The groove weakens the structure of the copper growing at the bottom edge of the cathode plate because the copper crystals grow perpendicular to the cathode plate from opposite sides of the groove, causing them to intersect at right angles to each other.<ref name = "Eastwood"/> A discontinuity in the structure is formed at the intersection that results in a weak zone, along which the copper splits during stripping.<ref name = "Eastwood"/>
Figure 4 is a microscope view of the cross-section a copper cathode growing at the tip of a cathode plate. The yellow lines show the orientation and direction of crystal growth.<ref name = "Eastwood"/>
====Low-resistance cathodes====
The standard Isa Process cathodes have slightly higher electrical resistance than solid-copper hanger bar systems used by the Kidd Process, meaning that there is a higher power cost.<ref name = "Eastwood"/> However, this cost is offset by greater reliability and predictability in the increase in resistance over time, allowing for maintenance planning.<ref name = "Webb"/>
The solid-copper hanger bars, on the other hand, lose electrical performance over a shorter period of time due to corrosive attack on the joint and sudden failure is possible.<ref name = "Webb"/> The maintenance costs of such systems are greater and less predictable.<ref name = "Webb"/> A trial of approximately 3000 solid-copper hanger bars, found over time a lower current efficiency in the solid-copper hanger bars of about 2.4%.<ref name = "Webb"/>
[[File:BR stainlessless steel starter sheets for copper refining.png|thumb|Figure 5. IsaKidd BR cathode plates.]] The MIM development team looked for other ways to reduce the resistance of the cathode plates and developed a new low-resistance cathode, which it called ISA Cathode BR.<ref name = "Webb"/> This new design extended the copper plating from 15–17 mm down the blade to approximately 55 mm, and it increased the thickness of the copper to 3.0 mm from the 2.5 mm used on the standard cathode.<ref name = "Webb"/>
The new cathode plate design was tested in the CRL refinery in Townsville and at Compania Minera Zaldivar in Chile.<ref name = "Webb"/> The Chilean results indicated the new cathode design had the potential to reduce power costs by approximately US$100,000 in 2003 for the plant, compared to using conventional Isa Process cathode designs.<ref name = "Webb"/>
====Lower-cost stainless steel cathode plates====
From 2001 to 2007, [[nickel]] prices rose from an average of US$5945<ref>P H Kuck, “Nickel,” in: ''Mineral Commodity Summaries 2004'' (United States Geological Survey: 2004), 114.</ref> to US$37,216.<ref>P H Kuck, “Nickel,” in: ''Mineral Commodity Summaries 2011'' (United States Geological Survey: 2011), 108.</ref> Nickel is a key constituent of 316L stainless steel.<ref name = "Eastwood"/> This, combined with increases in some of the other constituents of the 316L alloy, prompted Xstrata Technology (by then the marketing organisation for the Isa Process technology) to seek an alternative material for the cathode plates.<ref name = "Eastwood"/>
Xstrata Technology personnel investigated the use of a new low-alloyed [[Stainless steel#Types of stainless steel|duplex stainless steel]], LDX 2101 and [[SAE steel grades#Stainless steel|304L stainless steel]].<ref name = "Eastwood"/> The LDX 2101 contains 1.5% nickel compared to 10–14% in 316L stainless steel.
LDX 2101 has superior mechanical strength to the 316L stainless steel, allowing thinner sheets to be used for the cathode plates.<ref name = "Eastwood"/> However, the flatness tolerance of commercially available LDX 2101 steel did not meet the required specifications.<ref name = "Eastwood"/> Xstrata Technology worked with a manufacturer to produce sheets that did meet the required flatness tolerance.<ref name = "Eastwood"/>
Xstrata Technology also had to develop a finish that allowed the surface to function in the same way as 316L.<ref name = "Eastwood"/>
Cathode plates using LDX 2010 have equivalent corrosion resistance to 316L plates.<ref name = "Cathode">[http://www.isakidd.com/EN/IsaKiddTechnologyServices/Pages/CathodePlates.aspx “Cathode plates.”] Accessed 28 June 2013.</ref>
The LDX 2101 alloy provides an alternative to the 316L stainless steel,<ref name = "Eastwood"/> with the selection depending on relatively prices of the various steels.
====High corrosion resistance====
The Kidd Process development team modified its cathode plates to cope with high-corrosion environments, such as the liberator cells used to remove contaminants in refineries and some high-corrosion environments in electrowinning plants.<ref name = "Donaldson"/>
The design of the plate features a stainless-steel jacket that surrounds a solid-copper hanger bar, protecting it from corrosion.<ref name = "Donaldson"/> A corrosion-resistant resin inside the stainless steel jacket protects the conductive interior weld between the header bar and the plate.<ref name = "Donaldson"/> The hanger bar is then finished with high-quality sealing to prevent ingress of electrolytes into the conductive interior weld.<ref name = "Donaldson"/>
This corrosion resistance electrode is marketed as the HP cathode plate.<ref name = "Cathode"/>
====The Kidd Process High Capacity Linear Machine====
After the initial carousel stripping machine development and the later development of the linear stripping machine, Falconbridge personnel developed the Kidd Process High Capacity Linear Machine (“HCLM”).<ref name = "Donaldson"/> This machine included a loading and unloading system that was based on robotics.<ref name = "Donaldson"/>
The new design improved, among other things, the discharge area of the stripper. This had been a problem area for the carousel stripping machines, in which copper released from the cathode plate fell into an envelope and was then transferred to a material handling device.<ref name = "Donaldson"/> Copper that misbehaved and failed to transfer often required manual intervention.<ref name = "Donaldson"/> The new robot discharge system eliminated the free falling of the copper and physically transferred the released copper to the discharge location.<ref name = "Donaldson"/>
===The birth of the combined IsaKidd technology===
After Falconbridge’s 1992 decision to market the Kidd technology, the Falconbridge and the then MIM Process Technologies groups competed for the tank house technology market. Between 1992 and 2006, 25 Kidd technology licences were sold,<ref name = "Installations"/> while there were 52 Isa process licences sold in the same period.<ref name = "Installations"/>
Xstrata plc (now Glencore Xstrata) took over MIM Holdings in 2003.<ref>[http://www.xstrata.com/assets/acquisition/mim/pdf/XTA_MIM_Acquisition_Rights_Issue_07_04_03.pdf Recommended Acquisition of M.I.M. Holdings Limited for US$2,959 million and Rights Issue] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110812043939/http://www.xstrata.com/assets/acquisition/mim/pdf/XTA_MIM_Acquisition_Rights_Issue_07_04_03.pdf |date=2011-08-12 }}. Accessed 2 May 2013.</ref> The Isa Process technology continued to be developed and marketed by Xstrata Technology. Xstrata subsequently took over Falconbridge in 2006.<ref>[http://www.financialpost.com/story.html?id=2c7b0cfe-14be-40dc-8d92-8a74685e9782&p=4 “How Xstrata won Falconbridge,”] ''Financial Post''. Accessed 29 June 2013.</ref> The Kidd Process technology consequently became part of the Xstrata Technology tank house package and together they began to be marketed as IsaKidd,<ref name = "About"/> a name that represents the dual heritage of the technology.
The result has been a technology package that combined what were mutually regarded as the best of both versions.<ref name = "Aslin"/> This combination led to the development of new stripping systems and new cathode designs are in development.<ref name = "Aslin"/>
The variation in copper deposits on the cathode plates was one of the difficulties encountered with the earlier stripping machines.<ref name = "Aslin"/> Areas of thin copper on the cathode plates, which are caused by short circuits, are difficult to separate from the stainless steel plate due to their lack of rigidity. Plates bearing such areas generally had to be rejected from the stripping machine and stripped manually.<ref name = "Aslin"/> Similarly, sticky copper deposits (generally related to poor surface condition on the cathode plate, such as corroded surfaces or improper mechanical treatment), heavily nodulated cathode and laminated copper caused problems for stripping.<ref name = "Aslin"/>
Stripping machine development focussed on developing a device that could be seen as a more accommodating and universal stripping machine that could handle cathode plates with problem copper deposits without rejecting them or slowing the stripping rate.<ref name = "Aslin"/>
[[File:Robotic cathode copper stripping machine.png|thumb|Figure 6. An IsaKidd robotic cathode stripping machine.]] The result of this work was a new robotic cathode stripping machine.<ref name = "Aslin"/> It incorporated the following features: * a stripping wedge that starts removing the copper from the top of the cathode plate and moves down to the bottom * guides to support the copper during the downwards motion to ensure that the copper does not strip prematurely * rollers designed to reduce the friction between the copper, the cathode plate and the wedge during the downward motion of the wedge * grippers that clamp the copper before it is pulled away from the cathode plate.<ref name = "Aslin"/>
The stripping wedges are mounted on two robotic arms, one for each side of the cathode plate.<ref name = "Aslin"/> These arms strip the copper from the plate and lay the sheets of cathode copper onto conveyors for them to be taken away for bundling.<ref name = "Aslin"/>
==Advantages of the IsaKidd Technology==
Advantages cited for the IsaKidd technology include: * ''long life'' – the operational life of the permanent cathodes without repair is said to be over seven years under correct operating conditions for electrowinning applications and over 15 years for electrorefining applications<ref name = "Webb"/> * ''reduced labour costs'' – due to the elimination of the starter-sheet production process<ref name = "Eamon">M A Eamon and J G Jenkins, “Plant practices & innovations at Magma Copper Company’s San Manuel SX-EW plant,” in: ''EPD Congress ’91'', Ed D R Gaskell (The Minerals, Metals and Materials Society: Warrendale, Pennsylvania, 1991), 239–252.</ref> and the automation of cathode stripping.<ref name = "Armstrong"/> The average labour requirement for refineries based on the IsaKidd technology is 0.9 man-hours per tonne of cathode, compared to 2.4 man-hours/t for tank houses using starter sheets.<ref name = "Schlesinger"/> Atlantic Copper personnel reported a figure of 0.43 man-hours/t for the Huelva refinery in Spain in 1998<ref>P Barrios, A Alonso and C Ortiz, “Improvements in the operating practices at the Atlantic Copper refinery,” in: ''Proceedings of [sic] Copper 99–Cobre 99 International Conference, Volume III—Electrorefining and Electrowinning of Copper'', Eds J E Dutrizac, J Ji and V Ramachandran (The Minerals, Metals and Materials Society: Warrendale, Pennsylvania, 1999), 291–299.</ref> * ''no suspension loops'' – the suspension loops of starter sheets can corrode and thus cause cutting of the electrolytic cell liners.<ref name = "Hopkins"/> The lack of suspension loops also makes crane handling easier<ref name = "Hopkins"/> * ''improved cathode quality''<ref name = "Schlesinger"/><ref name = "Kordosky">G A Kordosky, “Copper recovery using leach/solvent extraction/electrowinning technology: forty years of innovation, 2.2 million tonnes of copper annually,” ''The Journal of the South African Institute of Mining and Metallurgy'', November–December 2002, 445–450.</ref><ref name = "Garvey">J Garvey, B J Ledeboer and J M Lommen, “Design, start-up and operation of the Cyprus Miami copper refinery,” in: ''Proceedings of [sic] Copper 99–Cobre 99 International Conference, Volume III—Electrorefining and Electrowinning of Copper'', Eds J E Dutrizac, J Ji and V Ramachandran (The Minerals, Metals and Materials Society: Warrendale, Pennsylvania, 1999), 107–126.</ref> – due to the straight cathode plates, which eliminates short-circuiting,<ref name = "Eamon"/> and the lack of bends and other surface irregularities reduces the capture of contaminants such as floating arsenic, antimony and bismuth<ref>C Wenzl, A Filzwieser and H Antrekowitsch, "Review of anode casting – Part I: chemical anode quality,” ''Erzmetall'', 60(2), 2007, 77–83.</ref> and other slimes compounds.<ref name = "Armstrong"/> The elimination of the starter-sheet suspension loops also improved cathode quality.<ref name = "Armstrong"/> In SX–EW operations, the use of stainless-steel cathode plates eliminates lead flakes and other debris from the cathode copper.<ref name = "Addison">J R Addison, B J Savage, J M Robertson, E P Kramer and J C Stauffer, “Implementing technology: conversion of Phelps Dodge Morenci, Inc. Central EW tankhouse from copper starter sheets to stainless steel technology,” in: ''Proceedings of [sic] Copper 99–Cobre 99 International Conference, Volume III—Electrorefining and Electrowinning of Copper'', Eds J E Dutrizac, J Ji and V Ramachandran (The Minerals, Metals and Materials Society: Warrendale, Pennsylvania, 1999), 609–618.</ref> * ''improved current efficiency''<ref name = "Kordosky"/> – this arises both from eliminating short circuits caused by bent and irregular electrodes<ref name = "Eamon"/> and from the shorter cathode cycles possible with the use of the reusable cathode plates.<ref name = "Armstrong"/> Current efficiencies of over 98% are claimed<ref name = "Webb"/> * ''increased refining intensity'' – this reduces the number of electrolytic cells needed in a refinery and its capital cost because the gap between the anodes and the cathodes can be narrower due to the lower risk of short circuits<ref name = "Armstrong"/> and because the current density can be increased, making the refining process faster.<ref name = "Armstrong"/> Refineries operating with the IsaKidd technology can achieve current densities of 330 amperes per square meter (“A/m<sup>2</sup>”) of cathode area, whereas a refinery using starter sheets can only operate at around 240 A/m<sup>2</sup><ref name = "Armstrong"/> * ''shorter cathode cycles'' – shorter cathode cycles are possible using the IsaKidd technology, which reduces the metal inventory<ref name = "Hopkins"/> and means that the refinery or SX–EW operator is paid more quickly * ''shorter anode cycles'' – the higher intensity of the refining also results in about a 12% reduction in anode cycle time,<ref name = "Armstrong"/> also reducing the metal inventory [[File:Bundles of cathode copper.png|thumb|Figure 7. Cathode copper bundles strapped for transport to market.]]
* ''uniform cathode copper sheets for ease of transport'' – the control over the dimensions of the copper sheets made possible by the IsaKidd technology, provides uniform cathode bundles that can be securely strapped and easily transported (see Figure 7)<ref name = "Armstrong"/> * ''improved safety''<ref name = "Garvey"/> – elimination of much of the manual handling leads to improved safety conditions in the workplace.<ref name = "Eamon"/><ref name = "Addison"/>
Staff of the Cyprus Miami copper refinery wrote after their installation of the Isa Process technology that: “It is now well proven that tankhouses applying stainless steel cathode technology can consistently produce high quality cathodes while operating at higher cathode current density and at a lower cathode spacing than those used in conventional tankhouses.”<ref name = "Garvey"/>
==References== {{Reflist|26em}}
{{Extractive metallurgy}}

{{Infobox person | name = José "Pepe" Fanjul | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = José Francisco Fanjul | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1944}} | birth_place = [[Havana]], Cuba | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | nationality = Cuban | residence = [[West Palm Beach, Florida]], U.S. | education = | alma mater = [[Villanova University]]
[[New York University]] | occupation = sugar baron | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | known for = | boards = | salary = | networth = US$8.2 billion (August 2017){{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-08-09/sugar-barons-amass-8-billion-fortune-by-mastering-u-s-politics|title=These Sugar Barons Built an $8 Billion Fortune With Washington's Help|author=|date=9 August 2017|publisher=|accessdate=10 August 2017|via=www.bloomberg.com}} | spouse = Emilia May Fanjul | children = | parents = [[Alfonso Fanjul Sr.]]
Lillian Rosa Gomez-Mena | relations = [[Alfonso Fanjul Jr.]] (brother)
[[José Gómez-Mena]] (grandfather)
[[Norberto Azqueta Sr.]] (brother-in-law) | website = }} '''José Francisco "Pepe" Fanjul''' (born 1944) is the second eldest of the [[Fanjul brothers]], who control a sugar and real estate business valued at US$8.2 billion. ==Early life== He is the second son of [[Alfonso Fanjul Sr.]] and his wife Lillian Rosa Gomez-Mena.{{cite web|url=https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2001/02/floridas-fanjuls-200102|title=In the Kingdom of Big Sugar|first=Marie|last=Brenner|date=|website=vanityfair.com|accessdate=10 August 2017}} He received a bachelor's degree from [[Villanova University]], and an MBA from [[New York University]] (NYU).{{cite web|url=http://www.llnyc.com/45007-board-approved-who-lives-at-960-fifth-avenue|title=Board approved: Who lives at 960 Fifth Avenue?|author=|date=13 April 2016|website=llnyc.com|accessdate=11 August 2017}} ==Career== Fanjul is the vice chairman and president of Flo-Sun, a Fanjul family-owned sugar growing and refining company, and of Florida Crystals.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/03/24/style/weddings-emilia-fanjul-brian-c-pfeifler.html|title=Emilia Fanjul, Brian C. Pfeifler|author=|date=24 March 2002|website=The New York Times|accessdate=11 August 2017}} ==Political interests== Fanjul is a longstanding supporter of Republican politicians, one of the largest contributors to [[George W. Bush]], a leading patron of [[Marco Rubio]], and has co-hosted a large fundraiser for [[Donald Trump]].{{cite web|url=https://promarket.org/sugar-industry-buys-academia-politicians/|title=Meet the Sugar Barons Who Used Both Sides of American Politics to Get Billions in Subsidies -|author=|date=19 September 2016|website=promarket.org|accessdate=13 August 2017}} His brother [[Alfonso Fanjul Jr.]] has been a leading Democrat supporter since at least 1992, and was co-chair of [[Bill Clinton]]'s Florida campaign. ==Personal life== He is married to Emilia May Fanjul, and they live in [[Palm Beach, Florida]].{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/northamerica/usa/7407253/Sugar-baron-robbed-of-jewellery-worth-millions.html|title=Sugar baron robbed of jewellery worth millions|first=By Tom Leonard in New|last=York|date=|website=telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=11 August 2017}} They also own an apartment at [[960 Fifth Avenue]], New York City. In 2002, the ''[[New York Times]]'' reported that Fanjul had "considered" leaving his wife for socialite Nina Griscom, with whom he had a "celebrated affair" (and who was married to plastic surgeon Daniel Baker), but had "changed his mind".{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/08/25/style/why-few-big-breakups-make-the-grade.html|title=Why Few Big Breakups Make the Grade|author=|date=25 August 2002|website=The New York Times|accessdate=13 August 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2002/oct/21/entertainment/et-baum21/2|title=He's rich in tales of high society|first=GERALDINE|last=BAUM|date=21 October 2002|publisher=|accessdate=13 August 2017|via=LA Times}}{{cite web|url=http://wwd.com/eye/people/suzy-746251/|title=Suzy|first=WWD|last=Staff|date=30 October 2002|website=wwd.com|accessdate=13 August 2017}} In 2002, their daughter Emilia Helena Fanjul married Brian C. Pfeifler, an investment banker with [[Morgan Stanley]], son of Mr. and Mrs. Brian D. Pfeifler of Gulf Stream, Florida.{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/maggiemcgrath/2016/08/03/brian-pfeifler-eschews-concierge-wealth-management-in-favor-of-getting-clients-into-uber-palantir/#28019f9bebd5|title=Brian Pfeifler Eschews Concierge Wealth Management In Favor Of Getting Clients Into Uber, Palantir|first=Maggie|last=McGrath|date=|website=forbes.com|accessdate=11 August 2017}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Fanjul, Jose}} [[Category:1944 births]] [[Category:People from Havana]] [[Category:People from Palm Beach, Florida]] [[Category:Cuban emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:Cuban businesspeople]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Florida]] [[Category:American billionaires]] [[Category:Cuban billionaires]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Villanova University alumni]] [[Category:New York University alumni]] [[Category:Fanjul family]] {{Cuba-business-bio-stub}} {{US-business-bio-stub}}
